Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6260, file 577-5, part 4)
Sir,

I have the honor to enclose herewith Voucher No. 570, in favor of Rev. Henri Poissin, for freight of materials supplied for the addition to St. Joseph's Indian Boarding School, Cross Lake. This Voucher is supported by the Copies of Bills of Lading, Statements and receipts of The Northern Fish Co., Selkirk, for the freight from Selkirk to Whiskey Jack. The item for boxes was to protect the lime where the bag were broken on receipt at Selkirk. I also enclose the Statements of Rev. Poissin of the freight from Whiskey Jack to Cross Lake. The weights are the same as the Fish Co's, and the charge of 50¢ is fair.

I may say that The Fish Co. claim an additional $74.50 on the freight for the boiler, as they state their charge for this was $250. for the trip, while it was figured and paid for by the Principal as 27,000 lbs. @ 65¢. I will be in Cross Lake shortly, and will take this matter up, and if correct, will later issue a further voucher.

Your obedient servant

The Aast. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Ottawa, March 24th., 1925.

Rev. Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 10th instant, enclosing a statement showing the expenditure incurred by you in connection with the addition to the Cross Lake Residential School, I beg to state that the part of the statement covering the time sheets is correct with the exception of a few minor errors, as noted in the enclosed memorandum which has been prepared for your information.

With regard to the account of $963.75 for lumber supplied by the R.C.M. mill, I beg to state that this account does not appear to have reached the Department. We have however received voucher No. 536 in your favour from Mr. Agent Gordon amounting to $646.10 for lumber material supplied by the Mission and the same was paid by cheque No. 1852, which was sent to Mr. Gordon on the 27th July 1924. It was assumed that this voucher covered all the material supplied by the mill.

All the time sheets and accounts received have now been paid and it is assumed that they have all been presented.

Yours truly,

F.H. Paget
Chief Accountant and Purchasing Agent.

Rev. H. Boissin, O.M.I.,
Principal St. Joseph's School,
Cross Lake, Man.
March 11th 1925

Mr John R Bunn Esq Inspector of Indian Agencies
Winnipeg

Dear Sir,

A few months have passed away already, since the last report concerning the works on the new Addition.

As we were delayed by the roofing papers, the mason work finished much later than we all expected; but nevertheless, favoured by a nice weather; all the outside of the whole addition was finished; the cornices all around the roof were painted; and the eaves pipes, all connected to the main sewer. About the Boiler, we want to tell you that we have had very hard time. We took six days to cross the five miles portage, and one day to load on our barge. Everythings were all set to leave on the next morning; but during the night, a big storm with snow came; and the waves pushed by a strong south wind, filled our barge up to the top. A good chance, we had her in a shallow place; there we took a day and half before we could have our barge to float, and the big boiler well balanced inside, because the least difference was enough to upset our barge, as she was not much bigger than the boiler itself. You can imagine the hard time we have had there.

In the last twelve miles in the lake, it went good; but we took 8 hours. The expenses amount to $220.00 and the North Fish Co bill is $250.; or $472.00 for the freight, from Selkirk to Cross Lake.

At the present time, it is set up to its place, and operates since three weeks. She will heat very well; but a big trouble arose about the chimney, which is too small. According to the size of the boiler the chimney should be about 432 square inches of surface, and ours has only 144 square inches. There is no draft, and to prevent it from smoking, we have to keep the draft doors closed. To remedy to that,
I was thinking to keep the present chimney for ventilation, and to build another one of the right size, near the other one, but inside; because it must disfigure the outside wall, and we will be able to build it in winter. We have already put in the basement, the heating plant electric fittings, cold and warm water, and sewer pipes.

We were thinking to have a plumber and a steamfitter, but as the expenses amount to a great deal already, we will do the work, and we are only glad because you have been so good to me. At the present time, we are making the concrete and cement flooring in the basement, and we expect to start plastering in a couple of weeks.

About our Storage batteries, to keep it in a good condition, we would need to clean it, but before touching it, we would need repairs. Just now it is working not too bad. To clean it good, we have to charge all the wood insulators, and even a few plates which are worn out.

We will be very thankful if you will be good enough to send us the following order:

1. No. 2 -- 17 Thyrax Exide Cells
2. 3 doz bolts and nuts
3. 1/2 doz Positive connecting Plates
4. 1/2 " Negative "
5. 9 " Positive Plates
6. 12 " Negative "
7. 4 Jars No 13 for same
8. 12 gallons of Electrolite

N.B. -- We never heard about the Big Wheel of our New H.P. Engine that we asked you to send us; perhaps she was sent to Selkirk; but we would be very glad to have it by the Railway, at Mile 137, Setting Lake Man.

Your very sincerely,

Assistant Principal.

Memorandum:

When the addition to the Cross Lake Indian Residential School was commenced, in 1923-24, $10,000 was available. During the year there was expended for materials and freight $1,821.64 and for labour $6,240.20 - a total of $8,061.84.

In 1924-25, $20,000 was voted to complete the addition. There was expended during the year for materials and freight $23,529.84 and for labour $8,116.40 - a total of $31,646.24.

Nothing has been voted for this addition this year, with the exception of the furnishings, which are not yet ordered. During the past two years, $30,000.00 has been voted and $29,708.08 expended. Hereunder are time sheets for labour, amounting to $2,666.00, and later, I understand, there will be an account for lumber amounting to over $900.

The expenditure has exceeded the amount provided and there was no provision this year for the last few accounts, as I understood that the building would be completed. However, the addition will have to be finished and furnished and I wish to recommend that the account for labour now on file and the one for lumber that will be presented in due course be paid.

Russell J. Turner
Supt. of Indian Education.
Sir;—

I have to report that I inspected Cross Lake Boarding School on the 26th and 27th of May.

The general health of the pupils appears to be good.

In the class rooms the work was excellent, as usual, and good progress is being made.

The grounds are kept tidy and in good condition. There are quite a number of trees on these grounds which were not cut out, and these make the surroundings much more pleasant than the bare open space often found. The outbuildings are also in good condition. There is an excellent garden here which provides sufficient potatoes and vegetables for the school. The unusually severe winter caused a loss by frost of some of the potatoes in the winter storage root house, so that while the school had enough for themselves, they had no surplus as expected. Hens and cows are doing well, and furnish their quota for table use.

The school building is in excellent condition and well kept. It is a good example of the permanency of the stone building, especially when placed on a solid rock foundation. Some of the rooms were not so spotless as usual, as openings have been made into the addition, where work is going on, and dust is continually passing in.

Work on the new addition is making good progress, and the building should be ready for occupation in the fall.

Your obedient servant

The Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Beaver Junior Drying Tumbler

The Beaver Junior Drying Tumbler is especially designed for Hospitals, Institutions and Dry Cleaners. It is also an excellent machine on account of the small "drop" for woollens in the Custom Laundry. The temperature and air control are so arranged that a quick adjustment over a wide range of heat is possible.

THE BEAVER LAUNDRY MACHINERY CO., LIMITED
TORONTO
WESTERN AGENTS: THE BEAVER SOAP CO., LIMITED, WINNIPEG
The end frames are solid iron castings bolted together carrying the whole load of the tumbler. The main bearings, which are Beaver Roller type, are supported on these frames but separated from the heat of the machine by an air space and a stuffing box.

The shell is of galvanized steel plates with lift-up door. The cylinder is of galvanized wire mesh. The cylinder heads are strongly bolted to steel T beams, making an exceptionally rigid wheel.

The reversing header is our Beaver ball bearing reverse movement, firmly bolted to the end frame. All gears are machine cut from solid blanks and are properly guarded. A simple and efficient hand turning device and gear lock is provided.

The fan is of the multi-blade type, has extra long ring-oiling bearings with oil reservoirs. While a speed of 1000 to 1100 R.P.M. will in most cases provide sufficient air, the fan is designed so that it can be operated at high speeds if desired.

Convenient clean-out doors are provided for removing the lint from the screens and the exhaust is so arranged that it can be either piped to the outside or a canvas bag can be placed over it, which makes a simple and convenient method of taking care of the lint.

The coils, of ample capacity, are housed at the rear of the machine, and the back of the housing is readily removable for inspection or cleaning if necessary.

Size and Style
The inside cylinder shall measure 30 inches in diameter by 42 inches in length, constructed of galvanized woven wire, and shall be of (Reversing or Non-Reversing) type.

Frames
Shall be of heavy cast iron, bolted together and connected by heavy stiffening angles, and shall support housing cylinder, fans, coils and driving mechanism.

Housing
Shall be of No. 16-gauge galvanized sheet iron. Shall be riveted to iron frames and made tight to prevent the escape of air and heat. The door shall be constructed of No. 16 galvanized sheet iron, hung on heavy wrought-iron strap hinges and securely latched by malleable-iron clamps, making it close fitting and preventing the leakage of air and heat.

Shall be equipped with clean-out door at bottom between fans.

Two upright castings shall be bolted to top of frames for tub door to rest against when open.

Cylinder
Shall be constructed of No. 23½-mesh, .410-inch diameter, galvanized woven wire, rolled after being woven, so that the intersections shall be interlocked. Shall be riveted to inwardly projecting cast-iron trunnions and re-enforced by wide hoops. Shall be further strengthened by four channels, riveted to trunnions. Shall be constructed with 5 galvanized cast-iron ribs projecting 1 inches into cylinder, securely riveted to the woven wire and bolted to the trunnions. Door shall be of No. 16 galvanized sheet iron, perforated, hung on heavy hinges, and fitted with heavy door latches.

Coils
Shall be located within the housing at rear and consists of 202 lineal feet of one-inch iron pipe connected at each end with right and left return bends.

Fans
Shall be equipped with 2 single fans of the multi-blade type 7½ inches in diameter, mounted on fan shaft beneath cylinder, for circulating air through the coils, and thence through the cylinder and out through an 8-inch duct leading to rear of machine. Shall be fitted with screened air intake. Fan shaft shall be equipped with renewable bearings.

Gearing

Driving Mechanism

Reversing type shall consist of one tight and two loose pulleys, each 10 inches in diameter, requiring 3-inch and 1½-inch belts, operating in connection with a worm and cam movement, producing a fixed number of reverse revolutions of the cylinder.

Non-reversing type shall consist of one tight and one loose pulley, each 10 inches in diameter, taking a 1-inch belt to operate cylinder. Cylinder shall revolve in one direction only.

Dear Sirs:

Your Agency here called for tenders for certain supplies of rugs, linoleums, window shades, curtains &c., on July 17th with certain numbers following the items. It states "descriptive or reference numbers given are taken from T. Eaton Co's Catalogue, Fall 1924 and Winter 1925. I have a copy in my office for reference." Perusal of such Catalogue, of course, gives no idea of the quality or design of the goods called for. We certainly would not buy from the T. Eaton Company one of each of the articles on order to submit quotations. We doubt whether the Eaton Company could furnish us with all the articles, for the Catalogue is now a year old. We issue a Catalogue ourselves and supply more goods to Western Trade than any two Wholesale Houses in Canada put together. Why not quote our Catalogue?

We think you will agree that no Catalogue should be quoted and that if you buy by sample these should be in your hands for inspection by prospective tenderers. That is the only way in which fair competition can be had. And an expert is necessary to see that the article supplied is up to the quality specified.

You will understand that we feel most strongly upon the impropriety of the course followed in the above instance.

Cheap tapestry rugs were called for. These we do not carry. They are not worth the price. Axminster rugs cost little more and wear four times as long.

Yours very truly,

JBC/B.
R. J. Whittle & Co. Limited
Wholesale Dry Goods

Dear Sir:

There has been difficulties regarding the payment of a freight bill to the Northern Fish Company of Selkirk, Man., account of Cross Lake School. There has been noticed by the Department a difference between the accounts of the Northern Fish Company and that of the Principal of the School for the transportation of a boiler. This boiler weighed 27500 pounds, which, at the ordinary rate of freight, viz: 65¢ per hundred would have amounted to $177.45 as the Principal had mentioned in this account, but the Northern Fish charged a special price of $250.00, making a difference of $72.55 which has been paid by the Principal, though only $177.45 have been reimbursed to him.

Would you kindly loop up this matter and advise me in order that I may communicate with the Principal.

Yours very truly,

Joseph [signature]

Memorandum

Dr. Scott,

A few weeks ago, the Rev. Principal of the Cross Lake Indian Residential School urged that an additional water storage tank be installed. The present tanks are inadequate, now that the building is enlarged, and there is insufficient water, particularly at night, for plumbing fixtures. The situation would be serious, of course, in the event of fire.

Mr. Orr estimates the cost at $700, and, as no funds are specifically provided, the request was refused. His Lordship Bishop Charlebois and Father Guy have left the letter hereunder and His Lordship informs me that there is really an urgent need and asked to have the matter re-opened.

I wish to recommend that a pressure tank be supplied, as I am hopeful that funds can be found from the coming year's appropriation.

Sir:

When I was speaking to Brother Cordeau about the pressure tanks for Cross Lake Indian Residential School, he opened up the matter of replacing the pipe of the main sewer of this institution with a larger pipe, 8" at least.

The old sewer pipe was 6", this appears to be too small to properly carry away all the material for discharge through this source from the school building with the increased accommodation since the new addition was completed. This was the cause of overflow or backing up in the basement.

The Reverend Principal makes mention of this, in his letter of the 6th instant, and asks for attention.

The length of this main sewer is about 500 feet.

Brother Cordeau is in the east at present, and he may be calling at the Department in Ottawa.

This is an important matter in providing for the disposal of the sewerage in a proper manner.

I beg to submit this matter for consideration, which is what I told the Rev. Principal and Brother Cordeau I would do.

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Brother Cordeau who is in charge of the Cross Lake Indian Residential School recently visited this office and gave me a detailed description of the damaged condition of the concrete septic tank. After making an approximate estimate of the work required to put this tank in working condition, I would recommend that a new tank be built, similar to that provided for the new Guy Indian Residential School, with a few alterations to the drainage system. The cost will probably amount to $2,500.00 in this locality.

It was suggested by Brother Cordeau that the sewage could discharge direct into the lake without endangering in any way the water supply intake, which is about a mile above the proposed sewage outlet. I cannot recommend this change unless a very accurate inspection of the local conditions is made. As I understand Inspector Bunn is familiar with this Institution, I beg to request that he be asked to submit a report as to which arrangement should be decided upon.

Sir:-

Your letter number and date as marginally noted above, is hereby acknowledged. This reply is belated, but the letter came between seasons and I expected to have an interview with someone from the Cross Lake School, so that I could get at the facts and write intelligently. I am now pleased to say that I had a visit from the Rev'd Brother Menard who is the man who looks after this side of the work for the Cross Lake Indian Residential School. He called on me on the 4th instant and we had a long talk that day and continued this on the 7th and 8th, these adjournments were necessary as he had to bring in certain information that became necessary as our talk progressed.

This was the first matter that we talked over. I find that the system is practically out of business. The Septic Tank will have to be rebuilt, the old construction was too light. Brother Menard will send correct dimensions so that the quantity of Cement required can be worked out.

The piping, cast iron, should be 8", and the quantity named by Brother Menard is 235 lineal feet, from building to mouth of discharge in running water. The old pipe was 6" and was too small.

A "Y" reducer is required, cast iron, the branches to 4" each and the stem of the "Y" 8" this connects the two feeders from various parts of the building with main sewer pipe, the 2 feeders are sewage conveyors, the main goes to the Septic Tank after receiving the discharges from the conveyors, the junction is in the building I understand. The enlargement of the main pipe is necessary to take proper care of the sewage, there are about 110 people, pupils and staff, all told. The new Laundry also adds to the quantity of discharge.

Summary:
A- Cement for new Septic Tank,
B- 225 ft. Sewer pipe, Cast iron, 8"
C- 1 only Reducer, "Y" arms 4", Stem 8",
D- Lead &c for making Joints.
Summary continued.

Brother Menard is to send correct dimensions of the new Septic Tank, see item "A".

I might now add that the purchase of the sewer pipe last fall would not have expedited matters as it would have remained at Warren's Landing for the winter I fear, so that the purchase now will be at Warren's Landing for the first boat of 1927.

All the piping handling sewage inside the building is in good condition, it is the main that wants attention.

These remarks cover the result of our long talk over the whole sewage system.

Rev'd Brother Menard, me the enclosed cut marked "A", on which I have circled "15", this is the boiler that he mentions as being required in the Laundry, the description is given on the folder. Brother Menard says that the condition of the boiler that is now being used is not in good condition. I told him that I would submit his statement for consideration.

The Rev'd Brother also asked for "steam Rubber Hose" 5 ply, 14" or 12" inside diameter. This is required in case that the water main intake freezes. He says that this has happened on account of low water. He would want 200 feet.

The following Implements were listed as required:

- 1 Plow, Breaker with Gouler, 14'
- 1 Stump Puller, and a wire cable for same.

I am enclosing a list of sundry school requirements, this is the original, I have made a copy of same, the list also mentions Bed Carriers, Clocks for Class rooms. A copy of the Blue Book the last issued is also asked for by the Rev'd Principal.

The Rev'd Brother mentioned a new stable with a good Hay loft, dimension 34' x 50', to accommodate 5 horses and 12 head cattle. He says that they can furnish certain lumber and that he will send in a list of the materials he would want furnished. I told him that I would submit this item for consideration.

He stated that he wanted a Magneto for a 6 h.p. International Gas Engine, furnished the School in May 1924. I went with these people and secured this Magneto for him, he took it back with him. Later I received your letter authorising me to procure this, by a personal selection as explained, this want has been well attended to. He also wanted a switch for his panel of the lighting plant, I found out that this was important, after a long search I located what was wanted with the R.A. Lister Co. I secured same for him and he took it back with him, this switch protected his battery. I will submit vouchers for these items.
and I will attach explanations thereto.

I asked the Reverend Brother about the possibility of discharging the raw sewage direct into the water but he says that this is not a workable plan and that it entails a lot of labor, and he also suggested that there might be some complaint about doing this. It is my opinion that Provincial regulations would soon step in, and that some severe criticism might be the outcome. I was getting a line on this matter as it was intimated in your letter 285-1-5 dated the 23rd April, 1926. I wrote about this but did not get satisfaction and a definite conclusion, so I preferred to hold it over and during the past season of 1926 I did not meet any one from Cross Lake, so that I was not clear about the details as I have able to place them with you now, after a talk with Brother Monard.

I have the honor to be

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Your letter, date and number as marginally noted, is hereby acknowledged.

We have your favor of the 10th in reply to which would say that our quotation covers exactly what is specified in your Order #399 were it not for the fact that the boiler is to be installed in the Province of Manitoba, and presumably comes under the Manitoba Boiler Inspection Law.

It is not a question of safety; the boiler we have quoted is a good boiler and perfectly safe if properly operated; but as we understand it the Province of Manitoba requires that all boilers except those used on railway locomotives and in steamship service, or boilers used in private residences smaller than 30 square feet of heating surface, must be built in accordance with the Canadian Interprovincial Regulations, and the boiler we have offered you would not comply with those regulations; but is our regular catalog construction boiler. It may be possible that boilers used in an Indian school are not subject to this inspection, but that is a point on which we have no information, and we would not ship this boiler for installation in Manitoba unless you relieve us of all responsibility of its passing inspection, and agree to pay for it whether or no.

We would like very much to sell you the boiler, but we cannot take any chances of shipping the boiler to this distant point and then have it rejected, as we believe the inspector would have a perfect right to do if it is subject to the regular inspection; nor would we care to furnish a boiler built to comply with the Canadian Interprovincial Regulations. Our reason for this is that the Canadian Provinces have adopted a special boiler inspection law which is different from anything else in existence and which operates very much to the disfavor of manufacturers outside of Canada. It entails a large amount of expense to get the specifications approved, and on account of not having a Canadian inspector in the shop there is a severe penalty in the shape of a higher factor of safety; and when the Canadian inspectors do come here to inspect throughout construction they make it just as hard as possible for the American manufacturers. We know of a case where an inspector was brought here to inspect boilers being built throughout construction, and in explanation of the amount of unnecessary work and changes that he insisted on he told the manufacturer outright that the Canadian...
Gurney North West Foundry Co., Ltd., June 14, 1927.

Manufacturers of boilers wanted to furnish as many of the boilers used in Canada as possible, and for that reason have made it hard for outsiders to compete. We are only giving you this information to show you how the matter stands.

If the boiler you have ordered is acceptable we will be very glad indeed to fill your order; but it must be with the understanding that we take absolutely no responsibility in regard to it.

Yours truly,

NAGLE ENGINE & BOILER WORKS,
E. C. Robinson

I might say that I was asked at what point they desired the safety valve.

Indian Residential School,
Cross Lake, Nov. 28th, 1927.

Dear Sir,

Your Circular #87 of September the 29th reached us in October by the last mail of the season last fall, so I didn't have the opportunity to answer it before as we had no other mail before the end of this present month.

I am letting you know that we have adequate fire escapes and that the access to them is easy even for the small children. We follow your instructions and the doors of fire escapes can be open by any small child. Fire drill exercises were given to the children, so they would know what to do in case of fire.

However, we are short of a few things in our fire equipment.

1st. We have no special alarm bell in our school.
2nd. We need two hose of 50 feet each, size 1½ inches.
3rd. We need two hose of 100 feet each, size 1½ inches, for the out-buildings like the warehouse, barn, carpenter shop, etc.
4th. We need ½ doz. Couplings to fit these hose 1½ inches.
5th. ½ doz. valves 1½ inches.
6th. 1 case of Pyrene Cans to refill our extinguishers.

With these few things our fire equipment would be complete and we will be more safe in case of fire.

Hoping that these details will satisfy you.

Yours truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Sgn. Rev. G. E. Trudeau,

For some time, representations have been made that a proper barn should be erected at the Cross Lake Indian Residential School. The item was omitted out of the Estimates for the coming fiscal year; but, following the last interview with Father Guy, I marked the request as fairly urgent.

Brother Menard, of the staff, has been sent out by the Rev. Principal and he is now in Ottawa in connection with the improvements that are necessary at the school. He proposes to get out the lumber and put up at least the frame of the barn this coming summer. The building could be finished in 1930, and, if you approve of the scheme, an item will have to be placed in our Estimates of a year from now.

A plan and a bill of material have been prepared by Beatty Brothers, of Winnipeg. It has been estimated that the barn, without sill (which is unnecessary at Cross Lake) would cost approximately $7,000. Mr. Durand sees that $5,000 is all the Department should be asked to put into a barn at any northern school, and I wish to recommend that an item for this amount be placed in the 1929-30 Estimates. The school management has a small lumber mill at Cross Lake and can erect the barn at a cost of very little more than $5,000, if they provide some labour by members of the staff and the older boys.

I believe the Department should let them proceed with the work and undertake to reimburse them to the extent of the Vote in 1930.

Sir:

Re Lighting Plant of Cross Lake Indian Residential School.

In the early part of January, 1928, I received a letter from Mr Agent Gordon of Norway House Agency, with reference to the Lighting Plant above mentioned.

In his letter Mr Agent Gordon made a recommendation that a New Switch-board should be installed, and he gave the firm name as placed on the generator of the above named plant. When I got this letter, I consulted with a form of Electricians, the Schumacher-Mackenzie-Kurmen Co., as I could not intelligently make out the facts that I got in this connection from Mr Agent Gordon's letter.

This Electrical firm asked a number of questions and these I submitted to Mr Agent Gordon for fuller detailed information, at the same time I wrote to Brother Menard who has charge of the lighting plant in question. Unfortunately Brother Menard had left Cross Lake by the time my letter reached there and it was sent to him in the east; he received it, he told me this when he called at my office on the 5th instant. I asked him if he had spoken of this matter when he was in the Department at Ottawa on or about the 22nd February, he answered in the negative, as the Brother is fully acquainted with all the facts, it was most unlucky that he omitted to speak about this important matter at the time he was there, he had my letter and knew what I required.

When Brother Menard was here we went to the Canadian-Fairbanks Morse, and I showed them the correspondence, and this firm told us that a New Switch-board was the safest solution of this problem, as this will insure safety.

Brother Menard told me that in the present condition of the Old Switch-board that there was danger of fire, and that they have been very careful about using the plant. This feature of danger of fire is a serious one and I fear that the safest and best cure is a New Switch-board that will safe-guard the situation in an absolute manner.
I think I have taken every care to determine what is the best steps to take, and I have come to the conclusion that the Old Switch-board should be removed and replaced with a New one and this should be done without any delay.

If a New Switchboard is decided upon, then this could be shipped to Cross Lake via the C.N.R'y and H.B.R'y via The Pas to Mile 137. I told Brother Menard that I thought this was the safest and best procedure and he agreed with me. It would have simplified matters very much if he had introduced the matter to you when he was in Ottawa on the 22nd Feb'y, the whole matter would have been closed by this time.

I enclose a memo of the cost of a New Switchboard which has been figured out by The Canadian Fair-banks Morse Co for your information.

I have the honor to be,
your obedient servant,

Jno R. Bunn,
4th Floor, Commercial Building,
Winnipeg, Man.-

Mr. A.F. MacKenzie
Acting and Deputy Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Dear sir,

In reply to yours (No. 123-1-5) of February the 24th let me first offer you our most sincere thanks for your kindness and for the favourable consideration you gave and that have always given to our school.

Re: Binder and farming mill information will be forwarded to the department by Rev. Father Lajeunesse.

As to the fire implements which you authorized Bro. Menard to buy, this was done through Mr. Inspector Burley, and I am glad to let you know that they are all arrived already. And so for the Jacked Theater, once more we thank you heartily.

We have been asking for almost two years for a new floor in the recreation hall of the girls and there was no...
The floor has not been renewed since the opening of the school and is in a very bad shape. Mr. Gordon our agent said at his last visit that we should have a new one. It is very bad for the girls feet especially when they are wearing their mocassins. So I am letting you know that it urgent and will be very pleased to hear that lumber (maple) will be sent by first of next week via telegraph, so it would give us the time to have it renew during the children holidays.

The dimension of the hall including the corridor is 54 ft x 21 which makes 1,134 sq feet. At $5 for the box 206 sq ft which will make altogether 1,240 ft maple flooring.

We would also need about 10 bags of King cement for a new coating for the tables of the children refectory which are much damaged and would have needed to be repaired long ago.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6260, file 577-5, part 5)
I have to report that on March 16th last I made a formal inspection of the Cross Lake Residential school. This school is managed by the Roman Catholic Church.

I found the whole building, dormitories, kitchen, dining room, corridors, etc., spotlessly clean and carefully kept.

I visited the stables and found them very well looked after. Because of the scarcity of hay, the number of cattle was reduced last fall. About four cows are now in milk. All are in good condition.

A good supply of vegetable for food for the balance of the season was on hand.

An additional area of about 15 acres, not on school or reserve property, has been cleared and broken, and is this spring ready for cropping.

The work in each of the three class rooms is good, and good progress is observable at each visit I make.

The children have an appearance which speaks of good health, good food, clean habits and clothing, and wholesome living.

An outdoor skating rink has been kept open all winter, a toboggan slide has been erected and is in use, and a hand ball court was just opening for the season at the time of my visit.

The septic tank and sewer have been completed, and this should solve the drainage question for many years.

The steam boiler and steam engine are now in the new position, and operate the laundry machinery satisfactorily.

New floors are much needed in the girls' recreation room and the corridors of the old basement. These are asked for in this year's Estimates. Also considerable painting should be done in the interior of the new wing.

There has been some trouble with the electric lighting plant. When the new switch board is installed, it will or should help materially. In listening to the operation of the plant, I am of the opinion that the 6 H.P. International gasoline engine used for this plant has not sufficient power, as it labors very hard, and cannot get up sufficient speed. I would recommend that a new engine, 8 H.P. gasoline or oil, of good rating, be supplied, to ensure proper service, and as a protection to the batteries.

This Institution is well cared for in every way.

The Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Your obedient servant

Indian Agent.

Sir;

I have to report that on my recent inspection of the Cross Lake (St. Joseph's) Indian Residential School, I found the bake oven so badly burned out that all bread baked in it was smoked black on the outside, and it was impossible to bake good bread. I examined the oven, and find it beyond repair, as all partitions are gone. It has been used for some twelve or thirteen years.

I would recommend that it be replaced at once. The old one is an "Oxford Portable oven, Gurney Foundry Co., Toronto, No.1382." A new one should be of equal capacity to this.

If shipped direct to the school, via Hudson's Bay Railway, to Wabowden, the school could take delivery at that point.

Your obedient servant

Ottawa, January 22nd, 1929.

Rev. Sir:

Mr. Agent Gordon states that on his recent inspection of the Cross Lake Indian Residential School he found the present bake oven badly burned out and beyond repair and recommends that a new oven be supplied.

The type of oven we supply to residential schools is that manufactured by Jean J. Daoust Limited, St. Boniface, Man., and is a wood burning oven. I enclose herewith a catalogue showing the various sizes of ovens manufactured by this firm. The Department is of the opinion that the Size No. 3 would be suitable for the requirements at this school. You will note that it has a baking space of 42 square feet, is 36" in width and 65" in height. I shall be pleased if you will inform the Department as soon as possible whether this oven would be satisfactory for your school, also if you have accommodation for same and whether its size would permit it to easily pass through the door into the room where it would be installed. When we have this information, consideration will then be given to placing an order for supplying same. You might furnish full shipping directions.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

I beg to inform the Department that a new engine for power for the lighting plant is required at Cross Lake Indian Residential school.

In April last I drew the attention of the Department to the fact that the engine used for this purpose was unsatisfactory, being under power. However it ran along until last fall, when the crank shaft broke, ripping the bearings out of the body, breaking out large pieces of the solid body. Fortunately, a good supply of wood had already been cut, and other outside power work done, so that it was possible to move the engine which had been used outside in for the winter. The old engine is beyond repair, and would not serve satisfactorily if it could be repaired.

The school authorities express a preference for the Fairbanks Morse gasoline engine, and state that one of this make, of eight horsepower would be satisfactory. I would recommend that a new engine of the type asked for be supplied, purchased in Winnipeg, and shipped north on the first boat to Norway House, or rather addressed to The Principal, Cross Lake Indian School, Cross Lake, where it will go direct to Whiskey Jack where it will be received by the School.

The engine now in use will be required for cutting wood and other outside work even before the new one can be received.

Your obedient servant

Sir:

I have to request that you will arrange to purchase and forward, for the use of the Cross Lake Indian Residential School, a 10 H.P. gasoline engine, to supply power for the lighting plant. The type of engine required is as follows:

Canadian Fairbanks-Morse 10 H.P. engine, Hopper cooled. Speed 350 R.P.M. Fuel tank 53 Gals. Belt pulley 16 inch,

also the following extras:

For Dynamo 21 inch pulley (for 6 inch belt) for Governor side on engine. Belt (leather) 6 inch in width, 24 feet long.

The above equipment should be addressed as follows:

The Principal,
Cross Lake Indian Res. School,
via West Selkirk,
c/o Northern Fish Co.

You should endeavour to obtain the engine at the lowest possible cost, and after the purchase has been made, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, together with receipt attached covering the cost of the freight charges.

We are informed that it will be satisfactory if the engine is shipped from Winnipeg about June 1st, next, to the address stated above, when it will go direct to Whiskey Jack. However, you are, no doubt, aware of the proper shipping directions, and will arrange to have the equipment mentioned forwarded when navigation opens.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Sir:

On my recent inspection of St. Joseph's Residential School at Cross Lake I found that the water intake had been frozen and that considerable work had already been done in efforts to get water, but with only partial success. A new pipe line had been laid over the ground, but the lift was too great and the water came very slowly, and finally froze in the pipes as the weather was very cold.

The very low water caused the freeze-up. I suggested taking up the old line to the foot of the hill, from which point it should be safe from frost, thawing the pipes, and replacing them above the ice and covering them with hay and sawdust. I agreed to allow them to get a number of men for a couple of days to get this work done without delay, which they did. I feel satisfied that they will now be able to get water, but they will have to drain the pipes during cold weather, and may find it necessary to use steam to keep the pipes open.

Misfortunes appeared to come together, as the water intake froze, the steam boiler developed a leaky flue, which had to be repaired, and the insulation winding came off the armature of their generator.

Besides the inconvenience of being without sufficient water during the time when the pump would not work, the building was without water pressure, and this would have been disastrous had a fire occurred. The line had been protected as well as possible early in the season, but the water level had continued to fall, and the line had been frozen several times, but had always opened for steam pressure before.

In this connection the following will be required by an early boat for replacing the water line for the future:
- 4 lengths, each 20 ft., galvanized water pipe, 3 inch.
- 3-45 degree elbows.
- 3-90 " "
- 6 assorted nipples.

I would also recommend that the floors be resurfaced and that the Department supply for this work:
- 1 barrel boiled linseed oil,
- 10 gallons floor varnish.

Your obedient servant

The Commissioner,

Sir:-

This afternoon at about 2.45 p.m., the Rev'd Brother T. R. Menard of Cross Lake Indian Residential School called on me in my office here. He arrived in Winnipeg from Cross Lake on Saturday, the 15th, in the afternoon, coming to the H.S.R'y at Wabowden (mile 137) then via The Pas to Winnipeg.

He informed me that the School has had a lot of trouble with their water supply for the institution. Trouble started on or about the 7th December, 1929. Since the 15th January, 1930 they have not had any water from the source of supply, and they have been providing water by hauling and delivering by water pails from the barrels to the several points in the school where the water is held for the various services; he said it took about 250 pails per diem, and in the cold weather experienced since the 15th January past, this has been quite a stiff job as well as an of considerable hardship in cold weather.

This trouble arises from the unusually low water, which is so low that the pipe conveying water from the lake to the school building is so exposed that it has frozen up, they endeavored to open up the pipe by using steam but this caused a split in the pipe, and until it is possible to get at the pipe and repair or fix it, the water will not flow. They tried to put in a temporary pipe line, but owing the severe cold weather, this was a failure, and also resulted in splitting several lengths of pipe by frost.

The Reverend Brother now asks me to make the above statement of facts, and that he would like to get assistance to put in a pipe line, to do this he would require 14 lengths 2" Iron Pipe, Galvanized. If he gets this it is his intention to put the intake of this pipe line in the current west of the School, here he says the water is deeper. If the Department decide to grant this request, please wire, and I can ship these materials to Wabowden, and from this point the Rev'd Brother can take the whole lot by team to the school and have the work done.

I have the honor to be,

your obedient servant,

Inspector

May 5, 1930.

Mr. Duncan Scott,
Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

We were much pleased to hear, in the course of the interview which we had with you on May the 3rd, that you were in favor of raising from its ashes the Indian Residential School of Cross-Lake and of going on with the construction of the Beauval school. Your kind words have relieved us from many of the sorrows and cares which have assailed us since the sad fires which have destroyed so many lives and so much valuable property.

Your decision of constructing no other but fireproof buildings for Indian Residential schools is highly commendable for its wisdom and prudence. The recurrence of such calamities as have taken place in the past is to be prevented by all means possible.

We understand that for this year, no substantial funds for building purposes can be relied upon. However, we should like to have your directions concerning the work which we might do this summer as a preparation for the building operations of next year.

We would suggest that an expert be sent to examine the walls of the burned school at Cross Lake in order to determine whether they can be used in a new building. As far as I could judge, these walls are still in a fairly good condition and as the stress in a fireproof building is not so much on the walls as on the inside pillars, I am inclined to think that they might be used to advantage. This of course would save much time and much expense.

O. Charlebois, O.M.I.,
Bishop of Keewatin.

According to a letter received from Rev. Father J.-A. Munsenese, our representative of your Department, it appears that you wish to know if we are expecting to see the Cross-Lake Residential School rebuilt next summer, that is in 1931.

In reply, I beg to say that we certainly do expect to see the said School to be put up again next summer and all the Indians of Cross-Lake expect the same. We are all confident that we shall not be disappointed. Therefore we trust that the estimates providing for the necessary funds will be prepared on time and presented at the next Session of Parliament.

We dare expect the same will be done to assure funds in view of completing the construction of The Beauval Residential School. This is yet more important, because there are already on the spot four carloads of cement which will be entirely spoiled if the construction is postponed to 1932.

Please endeavor to complete both Cross-Lake and Beauval Schools next year. In so doing you will make me the happiest man. I will be satisfied for good.

I will consider it a favor if you would let me know in a near future what you intend to do in connection with these Schools. We would need this information to see about getting our own work ready.

Trusting that your answer will be favorable in every respect, I remain,

Yours truly and gratefully,

Re: No. I23-I-5d Cross Lake School

Dear Sir:

Pursuant to your order of June 17th., I visited the ruins of this School and beg to offer my report as follows.

Walls which are built of Stone are still standing and with a few exceptions are in good shape. If a portion of the front wall, "see photograph 1", measuring 50 feet from the wall of the new wing was taken down to level of 1st storey window sill and first three walls between windows on ground floor to window sills. Walls of new wing adjoining, "see 2", also wall of new wing which faces the same direction as front, "see 3", were taken down to ground level. Wall on top storey facing Chapel, see 5, taken down for approximate width of 20 feet to 1st floor ceiling joice and wall on original building, see IO, taken down to top of 2nd floor joice and inside wall of top storey to 1st floor ceiling joice, which was the west wall of original building and these rebuilt with stone, all walls could then be used for new structure, including the rebuilding of all parapet walls on original building, or first three storey part of structure. A few places would have to be re-pointed.

All window and door arches and sills in original portion would require new brick arches or plastered with cement over present brick, also window sills likewise.

All openings would require new lintels on inside and portion over same rebuilt with stone or brick. Where face walls are blackened with smoke these could be re-pointed. Inside of all walls if used to be thoroughly re-pointed or plastered.

All floors in original building including basement floor were of wood. Provision could be made to insert Steel joice construction.

Present Septic Tank is in good, I might say first class condition.
Water supply intake pipe broken, would require re-laying.

All foundation walls are in first class condition, being all laid on solid rock when constructed.

All present chimneys are as perfect as when built.

If present walls, with the above noted changes are to be used, construction should take place before winter sets in for if walls are left as at present and become wet and freeze I would not like to forecast what would happen to them, but am afraid that they would further need to be taken down and rebuilt.

All entrance porches or verandahs to be entirely rebuilt.

All fire escapes to be new.

I am enclosing photos of present ruins which will give you a better idea as to the condition of the walls, numbers starting at front and travel right, around building. I failed to photograph No. 2.

If the department have the original drawings I could mark better the portions to be rebuilt; but, would recommend that re-construction be undertaken in the very near future if present wall are to be used which, in my opinion would be a considerable saving.

There is only the one interior wall, being the end wall of original three storey structure, and this with the exception of top storey which I have previously mentioned to be taken down, is in good shape with the exception of the openings, they will require jambs and lintels to be rebuilt.

I trust this report and photographs will be of material assistance to you.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

RNW/EM

Cross Lake June 30th 1931

Mr. Russell Ferrier
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

I believe this is the first time I am writing directly since our terrible fire. It isn't necessary to tell you how I felt at pretty bad, and I do not think I will feel really happy until I see our school rebuilt. I can't forget a day this most terrible night of my life. I would have rather die than see such a horrible accident.

It is so sad to see these walls standing there to break my heart. They do not only remember the sad accident we had but they make me also regret the nice things and the nice years I had passed in the school with our dear own little Indians, and now we don't have yet a comfortable place for the class room though we are using the church for classroom! If only we had desks for the pupils and the teacher it would not be too bad, but we have only benches and a little homemade table for the teacher. Last summer in July I had put an application to our agent Mr. Gordon for desks for the pupils and the teacher and nothing came. Last winter I asked...

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6260, file 577-5, part 5)
again for them to Mr. Gordon hoping we could get them by the first boat this summer but nothing has come yet though the boat has been to Wisky Jack twice and I had no answer about them from the agent so I thought I will ask directly to you hoping to get them before next fall. You know it's very hard for young children to write on their knees or to kneel down to write on their benches. Suppose that that you must have heard or seen by the Quarterly Return that there was no 50 children coming to class? So I also thought of asking you if the Department could not grant me at least a building like they have for day school on the reserves. It could be easy put up for next fall and this building could be use for other purpose, like provisions house, when they would rebuild the school. A building of 22 x 36 I think would be sufficient for the class room. I think it is not asked too much as we have been making great effort to keep the class going on. Most of the lumber could be got right here except the flooring windows & doors framing etc.

Well Mr. Ferrier I hope that you will find the way of getting us this building put up soon as it is rather urgent for us to keep the school going on the day school program.

There is another thing I will like to find out from
You Mr. Ferrier. In June 1930 when Foster, supervisor from the Post, noticed me that he had received the cheque for my quarterly return ended March 31st 1930. The amount of the cheque was $2471.87. So I looked immediately at my quarterly return and found out that the amount figuring on my return was more than that as it was $2972.81 so about $500 more than the cheque received and there was no explanation given. I thought I had made a mistake but could not find it. I wrote to the agent to look over my quarterly return and to inquire from him. I waited and waited but I never had the thing settle. I asked the agent two or three times so finally I decide to ask you directly. I would like to send you the number of the cheque as we should do when referring to a cheque but I lost the slip with the number. But telling that it was the cheque for my quarterly return ended on March 31st 1930 one month after the fact. Suppose that you could try to trace it and give me the explanation about the cheque. Hoping to hear from you. Don't you like to come by Cross Lake, we would be glad to see you.

Yours very sincerely,

J.E. Fredericton

Principal
St. Joseph's Road School
Cross Lake, N.B.
Ottawa, July 16, 1931.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, with reference to the situation at Gross Lake. The Appropriation for Indian Education has been so materially decreased this year, that I regret there are no funds for improvements at your school. The situation is known to the Department and your suggestions will not be overlooked for another year.

With reference to the amount of the grant for the March quarter, 1930, I find that on your return you ask grant for several days after the date of the fire. The arrangement with His Lordship Bishop Charlebois was that the regular per capita grant would be paid up to February 25th and that, from then on, special grants in lieu of per capita grant would be made from time to time.

Your obedient servant,

T. H. L. MacKinnon,
Acting Secretary.

Sir:

Ottawa, September 30, 1932.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your 379-1A of the 31st ultimo, with reference to allowance for midday meal for the pupils attending the Cross Lake R.C. Indian Day School.

As our Appropriation this year is limited, it is found that the maximum monthly amount the Department can allow is $30.00. If at all possible, you should keep the expenditure below this amount. Payment of the grant for midday meal purposes will be made upon receipt from you of a properly certified voucher, in triplicate.

The arrangements authorized in this letter will continue from September 1st, 1932, to June 30th, 1933. About the middle of next June, you should again communicate with the Department and consideration will then be given to the amount that can be allowed for the academic year 1933-34.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie.
Secretary.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

When I saw you at Ottawa in September you asked me to send you a bill of groceries &c. so you could reimburse us for the mid-day meal given to the children attending the R.C. Day School at Cross Lake. I am sending you one today for the year 1932-33. I am sorry I could not send it sooner as when I got back to Cross Lake Oct 19th the lakes froze two days after and it is only two weeks ago that I could reach Le Pas. There was no way of travelling or sending mail sooner, so I could not send you this invoice sooner. I hope that you will be able to refund us soon for this bill.

When I left Cross Lake two weeks ago nothing had been sent yet for the mid-day meal for the children attending day school. I suppose that instructions have been forwarded to the Indian agent at Norway House and that it won't delay too much before they get these...
supplies to Cross Lake.

Also about the bill I gave you Re. expenses made by the mission after the fire. I did not hear from you. I will be very thankful to you if you could also refund us soon.

I suppose you heard of the great loss we had last week by the death of our old venerable Bishop Charlebois. It was a great loss not only for us but also for the whole northern country.

Hoping to hear from you soon.

I remain

Yours sincerely,

G. E. Trudeau

N.B. I forgot to tell you that I had been transferred to Le Pas recently.

G. E. T.
Ottawa, December 5, 1933.

Dear Father Trudeau:

I have your letter of the 1st instant, enclosing accounts for food supplies used at the Cross Lake R. C. Day School during the period September 1, 1932, to June 30, 1933. Owing to the requirements of our Accounting Branch, I find it necessary to return these accounts to Mr. Agent Gordon in order that he can attach them to proper voucher forms and certify them. Mr. Gordon is being instructed to return the accounts to the Department for payment as soon as possible.

Permit me to point out that the Department does not usually supply such a variety of food as has apparently been supplied - this opinion is founded on a review of the accounts which show purchases of such articles as pickles, canned plums, shelled nuts, icing sugar, gelatine, raisins and currants. It is considered that only staple articles should be purchased and that the midday meal served at the school, while as appetizing and nourishing as possible under the circumstances, should not include fancy groceries. I feel you will agree with me that the Department's attitude in this matter is reasonable and that the supplying of only staple articles will result in a considerable saving.

I was extremely sorry to learn of the death of Bishop Charlebois. He is a great loss.

With kind personal regards,

Yours sincerely,

Rev. G. E. Trudeau, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Cross Lake, Via Norway House,
Man.

Sir:

In official letter of September 30, 1932, you were advised that the Department had decided to allow an amount of approximately $30 a month for the purchase of food for midday meals for the pupils attending the Cross Lake R. C. Indian Day School. We are now in receipt of the enclosed accounts for the school year 1932-33. These accounts amount to $283.73. I would appreciate if you would attach the accounts to proper voucher forms, certify and return them in order that payment can be made.

I wish also to draw your attention to the last paragraph of official letter of September 30, 1932. You will note that the Department expected you to write last June with reference to the amount that would be allowed for the academic year 1933-34. As yet, no communication has been received from you in this regard. Please let me have a definite recommendation stating what amount you consider reasonable.

You should point out to Rev. Father Trudeau that the Department considers many of the articles listed on the enclosed accounts should not have been purchased. It is considered unnecessary to serve a variety of food, and only staple articles should be purchased. By so doing, a considerable saving would be effected.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6260, file 577-5, part 5)
Sir:

I enclose herewith Voucher No.86, in favor of St. Joseph's Indian School for $283.73 for goods supplied for providing a hot meal for the children in attendance at the Day School classes for the year 1932-3.

Many of the articles enumerated must have been exchanged at the school for flour, fish, vegetables and meats. However, I am certifying the Vouchers, as I am assured that we have received equivalent value for the amount herein stated.

There should be no further difficulty of this nature, as the arrangement for the present year is the same as for the other Day Schools. This change was made at the request of Rev. G.H. Trudeau, who was then Principal of St. Joseph's School.

With regard to this latter arrangement, may I refer to my letter of Aug. 24th, 1933, in which I stated that the Rev. Principal had requested such an arrangement, and to Department's letter 123-7-5, of Sept. 13th, 1933, in which I am instructed to arrange a supply of biscuits for this school.

I have forwarded from my supply some 500 lbs. of biscuits as well as a share of the beans, rice, sugar, salt and cocoa supplied by the Department for this purpose. Owing to lateness of receipt, rush of freighting to God's Lake, early freeze up, and deep snow, making the muskegs bad for travelling, these supplies did not reach Cross Lake until the end of December. Since, however, the Indians had plenty of fish, and trapping was good, so that there should be a good supply of food, the need was not so great for a noon day meal, as it will be later. The attendance of day pupils was also small, owing to the epidemic of whooping cough.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Your obedient servant

March 26th/35

Mr. F.G. Lazenby Esq;
Indian Agent
Norway House

Dear Sir,

The Brother Menard and myself have been very sorry to have missed your last visit. We had to speak to you about our present day school. We will try to do that today on this letter. You have seen that day school. Although it looks not too bad we are absolutely obliged to pull down the whole building and rebuilt on a smaller scale and very simple. As it is now it is very cold; the roof leaks all over; the floor is all wavy (?). It is too big and practically impossible to repair because the walls and ceilings will fall down alone. The present building is 58 X 22 ft and we would rebuild 36' X 18' and will try to use all the good lumber out of it for first ply outside inside and flooring. For that we want the Department of Indian Affairs to give us a help by supplying the following materials herewith enclosed which materials should be sent if possible by the first boat of the Selkirk Navigation Co as we intend to do the work quick in order to have the building ready for next opening of school on September. The expenses will not amount to much more than $300.00 and it will make a good building, that could be very useful later on, even if the Department intend to build a new boarding school as we hope in the coming future.

In the confidences you will give to this matter your immediate attention and your kind approval which will be much appreciated, we are yours very sincerely

Signed; Rev Henry Boissin
O.M.I.
Principal

N.B. a small part of the building about 8' X 10' will be used as a little interior chapel

12th April 1935.

Sir,

I beg to forward herewith a copy of a letter I have received from Rev. Henry Boissin O.M.I., Principal of the R.C. School at the Cross Lake Reserve, accompanied by a requisition for certain building materials, for the purpose of erecting a new day school building, after razing the present building, and using what material that could be salvaged from that in addition.

When I was at the Cross Lake Reserve last month the Principal was away to Norway House, and I did not see him. I saw all the Sisters, but the matter of a new day school was not mentioned.

The present day school building, I understand was formerly used as the R.C. Church. It is a very roomy place, with a fairly high ceiling, and is a far better building than the United Church day school on the same reserve. However, I did not examine the building closely enough to find the defects mentioned in the Reverend Principal's letter, and am therefore not in a position to verify his statements.

The school was nicely heated, and very clean. I did not notice anything wrong with the floor.

However, if the roof leaks all over, that is a matter that should no doubt be remedied, unless the Department will accede to the Principal's request for the materials asked for, for a new building.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

Re - Construction of Residential School,
Cross Lake Indian Reserve, Manitoba.

As you are aware, the sum of $25,000 was made available for the above project and the Roman Catholic Episcopal Corporation of Keewatin was advised that this amount was all that would be made available by the Department for the present fiscal year.

Our Chief Engineer advises me that up to November 29th the Corporation had been reimbursed, under the terms of the Agreement, for expenditures totalling $21,467.78. Additional accounts have been received totalling approximately $6,726.00 and which includes $1,500 for a Chevrolet truck and $1,000 for material obtained from the Truscon Steel Company.

The Corporation, of course, are fully aware that the $25,000 has been overdrawn but are hoping that the balance might be paid when some future appropriation is made in regard to this reconstruction work. This information was confirmed by Father Grouard in an informal discussion I had with him on November 28th. The latter had hopes that some additional funds might be made available for this project by your Branch or through Supplementary Estimates for the current fiscal year so that the Corporation would not be obliged to finance the over-expenditure themselves until next year.
Would you kindly advise me if there is any possibility of additional funds being made available by your Branch for this project, provided of course the Minister is agreeable.

Director.

Dear Sir:

Re: Reconstruction of the Cross Lake School,
Cross Lake Reserve, Manitoba.

REPORT OF THE CROSS LAKE SCHOOL.

1) What has been done to date since August 15th, 1938.

a) The saw mill:

Our old saw mill was set up again after having been idle for the last four years, but several parts had to be renewed before it was in good running condition. The boiler also had to be replaced. The cutting, hauling, sawing and planing of about 64,000 ft. of lumber employed a crew of men quite regularly till the 15th of November.

b) The construction:

One of the first things to do was to clean up the fire ruins. Four and five feet of debris inside had to be dug up and the top story, at places the whole wall to the basement, had to be demolished. This work kept another crew of men busy for three weeks.

According to the preliminary plans, two stories on the wing, built in 1924, were supposed to be taken down too, but after due examination, the walls were judged by the superintendent to be in such good condition that he thought it would have been a mistake to have torn them down. The walls, therefore, were preserved and doing so by keeping the building at the same height saved the general appearance of the school and even gave it more room.

The saving of this story did not in any way affect the main skeleton of the building, but it did afford the opportunity for more spacious and better lighted manual training and sewing rooms. We are sending you the remodeled plans of the same.
e) Transportation of material:

While the above crews were busy, another was at work in the Whisky Jack Portage freighting the building material. As stated in my letter of October 11th last, we had to purchase a truck that was indispensable to keep the work going and to assure efficient service. This work continued till the first part of October and it was paid for by the weekly wages already included in the Return of Labour. Nearly 300 tons were trucked over a five mile portage, then unloaded and embarked for a further twelve mile water route, the whole necessitating several handlings before reaching the school grounds.

d) Sand and Gravel:

Through lack of time, we were unable to organize, as we would have desired, for the transportation of sand and gravel. The Indians were employed to supply both by canoe, paddling about a yard per trip, the wages amounting to an average of $2.50 a day. Though the procedure was not very economical, the employment of these Indians who were on relief saved the Government what it would have paid out anyway to succor these people.

e) Masonry and cement:

Favored by the weather and by the regular supply of material, four masons were kept at work right along till November 17th. The masonry is now practically over, except for the finishing under the rafters, the joining of parts of the walls, the completion of the window sills and the building of the fire-escape enclosures.

f) Concrete:

The plans for the steel work were well figured out and everything was made per requirements. This favored the advancement of our work considerably. Actually all floors are poured, except the top slab of the former chapel, (now intended for the boys' dormitory). Shortage of cement held up the completion. Nevertheless, all steel joists and other parts were finished to permit the building of the roof.

g) Present state of the building:

The work was kept up till mid-December. Towards the end, all efforts were centered on the roof which was
g) Present state of the building: (cont'd)

completely boarded and about one-fifth shingled. Since the 15th of December the building foreman and three or four men are working at reduced wages to stud the inside walls and make the window frames and partitions. All openings have been blocked and stoves on every floor protect the building against frost.

h) Expenditure:

The enclosed statement shows that the total expenditure up to this date amounts to $36,668.60 plus the expenditures expected to be incurred to March 31, 1939: $2,240.00. Grand total of expenditures: $38,908.60.

2) Work to be done:

a) Doors and windows:

As stated before we have not bought the windows and doors. Sketches of the various sizes were roughly drawn, enabling us to ask tender prices for storm, inside and outside doors and windows, amounting to approximately $ (See post scriptum.)

b) Heating system:

As for the heating plant, we are including something based on the former system which gave us satisfactory service. The old boiler was tested and if it was repaired, it still could be used. Riveted edges would have to be rolled over and tightened and a few pieces replaced. This boiler would be useful in case of emergency. However, according to your engineer, a new boiler is needed and we would suggest a "Spencer Boiler", Type 4S-1S. The tender price for this boiler and for the heating and plumbing accessories amount to about $. The repairs of the old boiler will cost about $200. (See post scriptum.)

c) The water system:

Four water cisterns, four by eight feet (4 by 8 ft.), were found to be in good condition and they were placed in the attic of the main building to give gravity pressure. The columns and beams underneath had to be reinforced accordingly.

Dear Sir:

Re: Reconstruction of the Cross Lake School,
Cross Lake Reserve, Manitoba.

REPORT OF THE CROSS LAKE SCHOOL.

1) What has been done to date since August 15th, 1938.

a) The saw mill:

Our old saw mill was set up again after having been idle for the last four years, but several parts had to be renewed before it was in good running condition. The boiler also had to be replaced. The cutting, hauling, sewing and planing of about 64,000 ft. of lumber employed a crew of men quite regularly till the 15th of November.

b) The construction:

One of the first things to do was to clean up the fire ruins. Four and five feet of debris inside had to be dug up and the top story, at places the whole wall to the basement, had to be demolished. This work kept another crew of men busy for three weeks.

According to the preliminary plans, two stories on the wing, built in 1924, were supposed to be taken down too, but after due examination, the walls were judged by the superintendent to be in such good condition that he thought it would have been a mistake to have torn them down. The walls, therefore, were preserved and doing so by keeping the building at the same height saved the general appearance of the school and even gave it more room.

The saving of this story did not in any way affect the main skeleton of the building, but it did afford the opportunity for more spacious and better lighted manual training and sewing rooms. We are sending you the remodeled plans of the same.
e) Transportation of Material:

While the above crews were busy, another was at work in the Whisky Jack Portage freighting the building material. As stated in my letter of October 11th last, we had to purchase a truck that was indispensable to keep the work going and to assure efficient service. This work continued till the first part of October and it was paid for by the weekly wages already included in the Return of Labour. Nearly 300 tons were trucked over a five mile portage, then unloaded and embarked for a further twelve mile water route, the whole necessitating several handlings before reaching the school grounds.

d) Sand and Gravel:

Through lack of time, we were unable to organize, as we would have desired, for the transportation of sand and gravel. The Indians were employed to supply both by canoe, paddling about a yard per trip, the wages amounting to an average of $2.50 a day. Though the procedure was not very economical, the employment of these Indians who were on relief saved the Government what it would have paid out anyway to succor these people.

e) Masonry and Cement:

Favored by the weather and by the regular supply of material, four masons were kept at work right along till November 19th. The masonry is now practically over, except for the finishing under the rafters, the joining of parts of the walls, the completion of the window sills and the building of the fire-escape enclosures.

f) Concrete:

The plans for the steel work were well figured out and everything was made per requirements. This favored the advancement of our work considerably. Actually all floors are poured, except the top slab of the former chapel, (now intended for the boys' dormitory). Shortage of cement held up the completion. Nevertheless, all steel joists and other parts were finished to permit the building of the roof.

g) Present state of the building:

The work was upkeep till mid-December. Towards the end, all efforts were centered on the roof which was
g) Present state of the building: (cont'd)

completely boarded and about one-fifth shingled. Since the 15th of December the building foreman and three or four men are working at reduced wages to stud the inside walls and make the window frames and partitions. All openings have been blocked and stoves on every floor protect the building against frost.

h) Expenditure:

The enclosed statement shows that the total expenditure up to this date amounts to $36,668.60 plus the expenditures expected to be incurred to March 31, 1939: $2,240.00. Grand total of expenditures: $38,908.60.

2) Work to be done:

a) Doors and windows:

As stated before we have not bought the windows and doors. Sketches of the various sizes were roughly drawn, enabling us to ask tender prices for store, inside and outside doors and windows, amounting to approximately $ (see post scriptum.)

b) Heating system:

As for the heating plant, we are including something based on the former system which gave us satisfactory service. The old boiler was tested and if it was repaired, it still could be used. Riveted edges would have to be rolled over and tightened and a few pieces replaced. This boiler would be useful in case of emergency. However, according to your engineer, a new boiler is needed and we would suggest a "Spencer Boiler", type 48-18. The tender price for this boiler and for the heating and plumbing accessories amount to about $ . The repairs of the old boiler will cost about $200. (see post scriptum.)

c) The water system:

Four water cisterns, four by eight feet (4 by 8 ft.), were found to be in good condition and they were placed in the attic of the main building to give gravity pressure. The columns and beams underneath had to be reinforced accordingly.
d) Electricity:

The wiring, fixtures and fittings amount to about $775.00. A Diesel engine to run a 5 kilowatt dynamo would cost about $1795.00; batteries about $825.00 for Globelite Batteries: 110 volts, 56 cells, C.D. 15, 13 plates per cell, 168 amperes, Int. rating. D.C.

e) Plastering:

Metallic laths and plaster for three coats which, without including the wages of the helper, laid at .25 cents a yard, will cost altogether about $6,700.00. Transportation of this material from Winnipeg to Whisky Jack Portage will cost about $450.00. (See post scriptum, b).

f) Cement, lime and bricks:

To finish the basement and the top slab of the former chapel and to repair some of the walls, window sills and chimneys, about 1500 bags of cement, 300 bags of lime and about 5000 bricks are needed. Cement for the whole at $2 a sack will cost $3000, transportation included, while the lime will amount to about $42, transportation also included.

g) Partitions and stairs:

We suggest for the partitions to use home-cut two by fours (2 by 4), covered with metallic laths. As for the main staircase, only the landing place at the basement has been raised slightly, the rest of the plans that you have on hand remain unchanged.

h) Water and intake:

A well will be dynamited this winter. An intake pipe will be extended 355 feet out from the shore into deep water. We actually have 200 feet of 3 inch galvanized pipe on hand, but we still require 220 feet more of the same kind and size. 150 sacks of cement will be needed this winter for this work.

i) Floor finish:

In previous correspondence, it was agreed upon to use plastic cement everywhere in the house, but after due consideration, we wonder whether it would not be advisable to lay
REPORT OF THE CREEK LAKE SCHOOL:

1) Floor finish: (cont'd.)

This only in the boys' and girls' playrooms, manual training room, outside students' room, basement toilets, etc., while for the corridors use battleship and in the rooms where there is less traffic some kind of linoleum.

2) Fire-escape tower:

For the fire-escape enclosure, since the school is now fire-proof, we wonder whether it would not be just as wise to do without this stone tower enclosing the fire-escape. Would just a pole with steel platforms at the floors suffice?

3) Gasoline-electric plant:

An engine and dynamo must be installed and since we have in mind a new European invention making gas from wood, we would suggest that a second hand electric plant be repaired and set up for a couple of years service, until this new machine, very much more economical, be adapted to our needs. There are three second hand electric plants at your Norway House Agency that could probably be utilized if the Department approves the suggestion.

4) Chimney:

To cut down expenses, instead of tearing down part of a good wall to put up the chimney on the outside, it was constructed within.

Hoping that this report shall meet your requirements and satisfaction. If any further details be needed we shall endeavour to furnish them as time permits.

Yours very sincerely,

(sgd) + Martin Lejeunesse, O.M.I.
Vicar-Apostolic of Kewatin.

P.S. The approximate price for doors and windows as well as the sketch for the heating system and the approximate price of the "Spencer Boiler" with the heating and plumbing accessories will be forwarded early next week.

If wood laths will answer the purpose, the price of this work could be considerably reduced. Further details about same shall be sent also by next week.
