Dear Sir:

In answer to your telegram of the 3rd instant concerning the Cross Lake School:

I am somewhat surprised to read in the telegram that "No authority has been given for purchase of equipment although accounts are being received from different firms." In equipment, for which accounts you may have received, I do not see anything besides desks and other school supplies that were ordered through the Indian Agent at Norway House, consequently following the ordinary procedure. By equipment, also, I hope you do not mean the electric system and lamps, or necessary supplies for the laundry and bakery. However, all these articles are listed in a report sent on request to the Department last January so as to figure up the approximate cost for the rest of the construction.

Since the school will be finished at the beginning of December, I hardly think it is the intention of the Department to leave it idle till the following September in 1940. Furthermore, since navigation over Lake Winnipeg will soon come to an end with the coming freeze-up, we took the initiative to buy only what was strictly necessary in furniture, dishes, beds, blankets, clothing. We have not as yet received the invoices to enable us to say just what will be the total costs.

As in all constructions, the estimate cost will probably be exceeded, but I do not think it will be above 20% of the $90,000.00. Furniture and fixtures strictly necessary for the school cannot very easily be omitted, unless a bare school is intended.
We hope the Department will understand the situation and that our efforts to co-operate with It will be seconded so as to make a success of the enterprise. I will be in Ottawa next week and I will have more precise figures and information to present by then.

Very truly yours,

[Signature]

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re - Sandy Bay and Cross Lake Indian Residential Schools.

As you are aware, construction work on the above two buildings was undertaken by the Oblate Fathers of Manitoba and by the Roman Catholic Episcopal Corporation of Keewatin, respectively, under authority of an agreement between the Minister and the Church authorities.

In the case of Sandy Bay School, the amount provided for by the Department in the present fiscal year was $40,000 and from information received to date it appears that expenditure made by the Oblate Fathers will exceed this sum by approximately $21,000.

Under the agreement for the construction of the Cross Lake School, the Department undertook to provide $65,000, and from accounts submitted it appears that the Episcopal Corporation of Keewatin has exceeded the sum provided by approximately $9,000.

I have been advised by the Chief Executive Assistant that the Minister is prepared to pay the accounts making up the over-expenditure to the extent funds may be available from the money provided for the construction of the Port Alberni School in British Columbia. At the present time it appears that some $34,000 may be available from the latter project and a Memorandum to Council is being drafted asking for authority to pay or refund to the Church authorities the amount of the over-expenditure as represented by accounts submitted. to you.

Dear Sir:

Re: Reconstruction of Indian Resd. School,
Cross Lake, Manitoba.

On the tenth of this month I went to Cross Lake, Man., where I passed a week. I am in a position now to give you a report on the latest doings on the construction.

There are still a few carpenters at work making transoms, screens, cupboards and finishing the fire-escape staircases. Another coating of paint will also be necessary nearly everywhere. There is enough work left to keep busy the carpenters now on the job until about the 16th of March. By that date it is understood that all work will cease and by the twentieth or so I will be in a position to send you the last paylist. If in fact by that time there still remains some work left, we shall see to it ourselves.

By the end of next month I will also send you the last bills: one from Wood Vallance for glass for transoms, one for mosquito screen for windows, one from Ashdown for hardware and the Compensation Board receipts amounting to about $600.00.

As already stated last December, I am very pleased with the work done at Cross Lake. Without saying that the work is perfect all around and safe from any possible criticism, I do say, however, and sincerely ask you to send Mr. Parkinson himself to judge the amount and the quality of what has been done. He better than any one else, since he saw the ruins before the construction, can give you a fair and impartial report.

It is with pleasure that I am herewith forwarding you a few snapshots of the new school and which will help give you an idea of the new edifice. Enclosing, I again emphasize my desire to have you send a competent inspector to examine the work done at Cross Lake.

Sincerely yours,

Department of Mines & Resources,

Indian Affairs Branch,  
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Re: Equipment of Indian Residential School,  
Cross Lake, Manitoba.

No doubt that by this time you have received the report of Mr. Buck, the Government Engineer who has inspected the Cross Lake School on the 7th of March. I hope that this report will be found satisfactory.

Yesterday I have forwarded to Mr. Mills the last bills to be paid in connection with the reconstruction. By the 20th of this month the last pay list will be mailed.

Please find enclosed an additional list to the one already sent (marked No. 1) on February 7th.

I also enclose a list of accommodations needed in different rooms with an estimate of the cost for wages. If the Department is not ready to grant the same, we will try to do without them, though they would be greatly appreciated.

A third list refers to tools needed for the manual training room.

The fourth list with explanations deals with an extra Diesel Engine and Frigid Air Equipment.

Hoping not to be indiscreet in submitting all this to your kind consideration.

I remain,

Yours very truly,

[Vicar-Apostolic of Keewatin]

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6261, file 577-5, part 6)
Department of Mines & Resources,
c/o Mr. P. Phelan.

This last list gives you an idea of what is still needed in the line of equipment. The prices quoted might change as most of these are quoted from catalogues. However, if you find that some items of lower values could be suitable, we are leaving this entirely to your discretion, as well as the buying of these furnitures. However, if we received authority to purchase these, we will do it the most economical way.

It is rather difficult to find out exactly the freight charges on these furnitures and if we consider that most likely there will still be many little things needed, in my opinion the expenses for the equipment shall amount very close to $9,000.00.

Hoping that you will not find this exaggerate.

Yours truly,

The R.C. Episcopal Corporation of Keewatin.

October 15th, 1940

Dear Sir:

I have been greatly disappointed when I saw the beds bought by the Department for our school. They are too wide to be suitable for the dormitories and moreover they don't match those bought last fall from Ashdown Company. If you look down on the invoice No.65563, you will find out that there were:

15 Bungalow Beds No.57 2'6" x 6'
35 " " " 2'5½"x 5'6"

The beds bought from the Globe Bedding Co. on September 7th, are:

29 Bungalow Beds 4' 6" x 3'
26 " " 5' X 3'

I wonder what is the reason that they are so wide as it is not necessary for comfort and as they would look more proportionated if they were narrower as they are shorter. The main objection I have is, that they take too much floor space uselessly. With these it means that we lose fourteen feet of floor space in each dormitory. There is no doubt it would be too crowded. Hence, in my opinion, they have to be returned and so the mattresses, at any cost.

What makes me more sorry about it, is that besides the additional cost for transport, I am sure there is depreciation on the beds as they are in a certain way damaged. The water is so low this fall that the barge can not come to dock at our warehouse. They have to unload out on a point. From there we haul the freight by canoe. It is where the beds were unloaded. The first day the boat arrived, we hurried up to get in the shed all perishable goods. We did not have time to put the beds in. They were left outside well covered. The next day it has rain all day. Too much dampness and possibly rain have caused the cable fabric to rust on some of them.

If I have had been there when the boat came, I would have reshipped them at once. When I was aware of the kind of beds we had received, the boat was gone.

They were left on this point for the next boat that was supposed to come only this week. Without giving us any notice, I hear they have come last week. What have they done with the beds, I can not say. More likely, they should have have taken them on the boat and reshipped them to the Globe
I would have liked to have your advice before taking any action. I could not delay any more as, undoubtedly, it is the last boat this fall. I would not have cared to keep them over winter as very probably they would have received more damage, especially the mattresses which would have been spoiled by the mice.

I had no opportunity to take information from Father Trudeau. It would have been too late to send them back.

I understand plainly you will feel sorry about it, but I should think you will approve what I have done, realizing that smaller beds meet far better the needs. I had even asked Father Trudeau to try to get 24" width for the 4' 6" beds.

I have to point out to you also that on your Purchase Order the five foot beds are quoted at $6.97. On the Manufacture invoices they are charged at $9.97.

It would not be possible and practical to buy smaller beds this fall and have them shipped out by railway. The winter roads are not good enough for that purpose and the freight would amount too much. The only thing to do is to wait until next spring to have them in. It will be awkward to do without them this winter, but I think we will have to.

I would ask you to buy the mattresses now and have them shipped out by rail around November 20th. The length for the beds and mattresses is correct, but the width should not be more than 2' 5½". Address them Via Wabowden C/O A. Pieroni.

At the exception of the sewing machines, I have not yet received anything else of what was purchased. More likely it has arrived on last week boat and as it has been outside under cover for pretty near a week I wonder how these furnitures will be.

I feel really sorry to give you so much trouble and to seem to be dissatisfied, although I understand that lots has been done for us. I can not help it, it has to be done. However, I would like you to rest assure of our gratitude. If these shipments had been done earlier, lots of troubles, expenses and lost could have been avoided.
I hope this experience will convince you of the importance to clear every matter regarding the northern districts as soon as convenient in the early summer.

As soon as the merchandises arrive, I will endeavour to send the certified invoices. They may be late as it may freeze up before I have time to send them in.

Yours very truly,

A. Chamberland, O.M.I.
Principal.

Dear Father Plourde:

I enclose, for your information, a copy of a letter which has just been received from Rev. Father Chamberland, Principal of the Cross Lake Residential School. This letter explains itself and I must say at the outset that it is difficult to understand why the Principal took the action outlined in the letter. At the present time, when it is becoming increasingly difficult to obtain deliveries of goods, and when the Department supplied good serviceable beds of a reasonable width, it is beyond me why any Principal should return them.

After all is said and done the Department should have some say as to the width of beds that are used in residential schools. Apparently the Principal of the Cross Lake School does not recognize this fact.

In addition you can see from his own letter that the beds were left outside for a considerable period of time and even now he does not apparently know where they are. He refers in the first paragraph of his letter to beds which he purchased himself from the Ashdown Hardware Company. This is one of the accounts which have been forwarded here for payment and it shows that the beds cost $8.50 apiece whereas we purchased them for $6.97 each.

I have not yet heard from the Globe Bedding Company but I think both of us can be assured that when the beds finally are returned to them, if they ever arrive, we are going to have a very interesting time in endeavouring to straighten out the matter.

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
619 McDermot Avenue,
Winnipeg, Man.
I dislike bothering you with this matter but I was afraid that if I wrote to the Principal I would say something that might be better left unsaid.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

The only information we could get from the gentleman in charge of the Selkirk Navigation Company, was that they were returned to them without any explanation except for a remark made by the Captain of the ship, that the beds had been made on the wrong size. The Navigation company has asked us to pick up these beds and springs within a few days.

We checked up on the beds and springs and found that they were made exactly according to the specifications given us, and we cannot understand why they have been returned to us, as the mattresses were not returned, and they were made to fit the beds. We have received no advice whatsoever from the Rev. A. Chamberland, and we are therefore writing to you in the hope that you will be able to enlighten us on this matter. We are sending a copy of this letter to Rev. A. Chamberland.

As mentioned above the beds and springs are now in the possession of the Selkirk Navigation Company, and we would therefore appreciate a reply at your earliest convenience. Thanking you, we are,

Yours truly,

GLOBE BEDDING COMPANY, Limited.
(per) J. Miller
Sales Department.

Reverend Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of the 15th ultimo with reference to the beds supplied for the Cross Lake Indian Residential School.

Re: Cross Lake Residential School, Manitoba.

In connection with the above project, you will recall that in October, 1938, a truck was purchased by the R.C. While the Cross Lake Indian Residential School was under construction the Church authorities purchased a truck in order to freight supplies at Whiskey Jack Portage. This truck is consequently the property of the Department. I recently wrote to the Principal to ascertain the purpose for which the truck is now being used and he has replied as follows:

"This machine has been exclusively used for freighting at Whiskey Jack Portage, and is left there, twelve miles from the school. Cross Lake, June 17th, 1943

Dear Sir:

The work for the completion of our school has been going on steadily although not in a very extensive way, as we had no special grant to complete this building; we had to do it at our own expenses and consequently choose the most economical means even if it is slow. There are still different things to be done to say it is completed and finished. I hope that by next fall it will be all done. Regarding the accommodation it will take all the winter to do it. We have a man working regularly on this job. His work can not show much on a building of this dimension.

We are very satisfied with the construction, water, electric and heating plans. They have worked perfectly and have not given any trouble yet. However, I would advise that another "Diesel Engine" be installed. We have only one engine to drive all our machines; water pump, generator, laundry and dough mixer. We have also an electric pump for the return of the heating plan. We would be in a very complete disorganization should it happen that this engine gets out of order yet it is but a natural thing to expect. As we are in a distant location it would take weeks before we could have the repair parts. I would strongly suggest that the Department send us another engine. I am convinced it is a very wise organization to do.

Since the opening of the school, we have realized that some changes have to be made in the partitions. It would be more convenient. I am sorry we could not have foreseen it and have it done at first.

The chapel has proven too small. We have to crowd to a certain extent the children, the organ and the confessional take many feet of room. It could be easily extended if we would take down the wall between the chapel and the solarium and add this room to the chapel. On the other hand the solarium is too far away from the infirmaries and there is no accommodation for the sick people. I have taken the matter up with the Department Doctor, Dr. Cameron Corrigan, from Norway House, and he said that our infirmaries are large enough and plenty of sun shine to meet our needs. Consequently I think this wall should be taken down and use the full room as a chapel.

On the first floor, it would also be more accommodating if the wall between the Principal's Office and the class room be demolished and the full room use for the "babies' " class room. We had provided for four class rooms. The fourth one is too small to be practical. Besides, I think it would be always a problem to have so many teachers. A larger class room would be better and I think give good results as in pretty near all the Indian Residential Schools there are no more than three class rooms. The Principal's Office would be located in this fourth class room. This would be better arranged. The Principal's office is really too narrow and too far from the parlor. If it would be in this fourth class room a door would be opened direct on the parlor and give more accommodation for all.
I am sending you the plans and I ask to be given authorization to have these changes done. I should say that it is my intention to have it done at our own expense and I can assure that the work will be neatly done. I would like to know at a very early date as it should be done in the first part of the holidays so we could do the painting we have to do after. I want to say again that this is practically necessary.

I hope that you have been pleased with Mr. Buck's report when he visited the school. He seemed to be very satisfied. We have endeavoured to do the very best we could according to circumstances in which it had to be put up.

Hoping to hear from you at your earliest convenience,

I remain,

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) Albert Chamberland, O. M. I.
Principal.

Dear Sir:

Attention Mr. Philip Phelan

Since receiving your letter of July 16th regarding proposed changes in the partitions of a few of the rooms of the Cross Lake Residential School, I wrote to His Excellency Bishop M. Lajeunesse, O.M.I. and received an answer to my letter this morning.

His Excellency was himself very much surprised to learn that some of the changes were advisable if not quite necessary. He attributes this to the want of experience of both Rev. Father Chamberland and the Mother Superior in charge of the School.

Of all the changes proposed, His Excellency advises there is one which is imperative, and that is the enlarging of the classrooms for the very small children. This is to be done at the expense of the Principal's office. As far as the chapel is concerned, His Excellency admits that it is rather small, but will not advise enlarging it by doing away with the solarium, unless the Doctor advises that this solarium is of no practical utility, and that the School can very well get along without it.

The question of the supplying of a Diesel engine is one to which the Department should give careful attention. It should be borne in mind that Cross Lake is about 400 miles from Winnipeg and there are times during the year when it would take about six weeks for repair parts to be shipped from Winnipeg. The heating plant depends for its proper functioning on an electrically-operated condensation pump. Should the Diesel engine break down in the Winter, there would be no way of operating the heating plant. Great damage might result in the freezing of the radiators and the plumbing system.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Indian Residential School,
Cross Lake, Manitoba.

With reference to your notation of the 9th ultimo on the memorandum dated August 8th last from the Acting Director of the Indian Affairs Branch, it is noted that authority has been issued to the Church officers to enlarge the class room on the first floor, as indicated on the sketch submitted by Father Chamberland, Principal of the School, with his letter dated June 17th, 1941. It is understood that removal of the partition between the chapel and solarium, suggested by Father Chamberland at that time, was found to be unnecessary.

It is further noted that the Church authorities again refer to the purchase of a second Diesel engine to provide current for the electrical system at the school in the event of a breakdown of the engine now installed. A breakdown of the engine would of course prevent operation of the electrically operated condensation return pump on the heating system, and the school Principal has suggested the installation of a hand operated pump for use in such an emergency.

As far as we have been able to discover after investigation, no manually operated equipment for use in returning condensate to a boiler is manufactured, and in our opinion no such equipment is necessary.

There is no possibility of the heating system freezing up due to the failure of the condensation pump. Condensate in the return steam line would not be removed, and would build up in the return line to the volume usually eliminated by the electrically operated pump. When this point was reached, the vent with which the pump is equipped would allow additional condensate to spill out on the boiler room floor; but, provided the water level in the low pressure heating boiler was maintained, nothing more serious would result.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
From the information available, it would seem that the heating system is working satisfactorily and that the only justification for considering the installation of additional equipment would be to ensure continuous operation of the electrical system in the event of a temporary breakdown of the present installation.

Respectfully submitted,

Chief Engineer.

March 26, 1943.

Memorandum

THE DIRECTOR

Dr. Moore's Report on a trip in Northern Canada.

I inspected the Cross Lake Residential School and found it clean and well kept. Father Trudeau drew my attention to the fact that there is no standby source of power and that if anything happened to the engine they would not be able to heat or light the building or have any water whatever. This would be a serious condition if the engine broke down in cold weather as the fire would have to be put out immediately due to the fact that there would be no water available for the boiler. The school itself is very well constructed, but very poorly designed. The building is narrow for its length and the rooms are of an awkward size. There does not seem to be sufficient class room space.

P.E. Moore, M.D., D.P.H.,
Acting Superintendent of Medical Service

Dear Parents, Benefactors, Benefactresses,

I was anxious to write to you. I should have waited to be in Chagona to do it but Reverend Fathers Rémy and Chaput are just like you and they willing to give me a help so here I am. Yes, I am not home yet as I have still forty or fifty miles to travel, a two days trip. I thought I could have gone by trucks but I heard today that the trucks are not going in that direction on account of the snow and as they cannot buy fish there is no reason to go, so I will have to find another way of going... I will go in a canoe or the other. My Montagnais seem to be lonesome. No Father! I was reading this morning a letter from one of them and he said "Time is long when we have no Father." No Father, it is true, how I will be lonesome once more in my little house, nobody to help me, no one to speak with... but I must remember that the life of a priest must be a perpetual sacrifice.

Now I will tell you what I did on my way back. I met good people all over and everywhere. First I stopped at Three Rivers, after I left Quebec, then Cap-de-la-Madeleine, and Montreal. I tried to pay a visit to all those who have been so kind to me and generous to my mission. I wanted to visit too the parents of our Fathers but they were too many it was impossible. I was really sorry. It was impossible to ask me to these different places when we know that the gas is rationed on account of the war, so with the tires. At Ottawa the good brothers the "Schlastics" have been kind and sympathetic, they did not seem to pay attention to my language and manners which resemble (involuntarily) to the languages and manners of my people. At Toronto I met several persons who did not know what to do to help the Missions. We are all Canadians, so all brothers, of course this is what we should be. To all my most sincere thanks.

From Winnipeg to Le Pas, as I went to see His Excellency Bishop Lajeunesse, I met several Fathers. Time flew in such company. I stopped at Saskatoon, at St. Paul's Hospital where I met the good Sister Buckley and Sister Vincent, the Superior. They have been so kind to me that I have no words to express my gratitude. I also went to the Academy of Sion. I saw the Superior and the pupils. I also met there a Canadian, a well cultivated person. At St. George-de-Beauce. From North Battleford to Meadow-Lake we took a whole day to travel one hundred miles. This remembered me my dogs sleds. As the Oblates are found everywhere I was well received by them everywhere.

On Wednesday morning I took the truck for Ile-a-la-Crosse. We had a few incidents. We had to shovel the snow once in a while to avoid trucks left along the road. I had my dinner with Brother Berne-Rolland at Green Lake. Finally I was at Ile-a-la-Crosse at two o'clock the next morning. When there is a will there is a way... we finally arrived here. I think it would be wiser to stop now even if I have some more to say because if I wait to continue at Chagona I do not know when I could finish it. I am persuaded that I will not have peace for a while there, and I wish to thank you you have been so kind to me.

My sincere thanks to all the Parish Priest and their Vicars who have been so kind to me in all ways. Thanks also to you all dear parents, benefactors, benefactresses. To you all I desire to express my most heartfelt wishes for a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year. During the solemn moment of Mass, every morning I pray God to bestow on you His most Precious Blessings. May the Almighty give you strength to bear the heavy burden of sufferings of the present life.

Thanks to you all.

Your grateful missionary in Our Lord and Mary Immaculate

L. Morand omi

Dear parents benefactors and friends,

I am back again, at my mission of Chagona.

It is to relate you how I reach my mission, that I write to you this present letter.

I assure you, that I started to come here, without expecting at all. I was not quite rest from the fatigues of the journey, between Fondow Lake and Islo & La Grosse.

I traveled hundred and fifty miles by truck. Some places the wheels of our truck were sunk in the banks of snow. Then we took the shovels and remove the snow. Place by place we see some broken trucks a side of the road. They left one just on the middle of the road we had quite a job to pass beside. A terrible blizzard passed in the north, about the middle of the month of November. Since that storm, some trucks had past, and had crush the snow, but it was still bad when we past our selves. Finally, we arrived at Islo & La Grosse, at two o'clock in the morning. I thought at first, that I could reach my Chagona's mission by truck. The doctor was supposed to go himself, by truck. I made my plans to start with him. But at the last moment, he send me a little note, telling me, that we had to renounce to go to Chagona, by truck, because the snow was too heavy. Then, I was resigned to wait until the next Monday, and to hire a man with his sleigh and a team of horses. If we could find any, who would be willing to come. Mean while, I decided to write you a printed letter, to each one of you; with the aid of Fathers Remy and Chaput. We just began to print it. Behold, the doctor enter in the house, like a gust of wind, and yelling: Father Morand, be in a hurry, we start for Chagona, by aeroplane, on five minutes. The arms pretty near, have fallen no down, like we say in French. He took me unaware, the doctor. I all ready renounced to start. All the supplies, that I brought from Fondow Lake, I had to leave them behind me.
I had no friend nor host at Chicoutimi; I would not be very anxious to begin to take back immediately; in arriving, But it was difficult, to let pass a so good chance, to reach my mission rapidly. To leave the letter, not even outlining, and I begin to pick my baggage... All was well, on the floor, a true bazaar. Father Remy and Chaput give me a help. I carry with me the most needful things. Father Remy assured me to send the rest by the first chance. I tell a last "Bonjour" to my dear Confreres, and we fly towards Chicoutimi. After half an hour of flight, I perceive from the air, the chapel, my house, the shocks of the Indians. No body was at the landing to meet me. I arrive at my house, I unbar the door, I light the fire in the stove, go to the lake, with my kettles to get water. I re-began my life of solitude, of and hermit, my life of "Bachelor". I tell you, I was obliged like we say in French to take my courage with my both hands. To not let me go to the discouragement. My house was not quite warm, that the Montagnais and Montagnaises, arrive to shake hands to me, and says: "Sotrain shu horinlo". It means to say: that they found the time long, since I left the mission.

Dear parents, I think to you often. I remember often what kindnesses you had for me. I visit you almost every day, with my mind and my heart. I pray for you every day, the Good God, that He spread on each one of you, His most copious blessings. I wish to you all a merry Christmas, and a Good and Happy New Year; and the Paradise at the end of your days.

I am your Grateful missionary in our Lord and Mary Immaculate.

Louis Léonard

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I am in receipt of a letter from Right Reverend M. Lajeunesse, O.M.I., Vicar-Apostolic of Keewatin, pointing out the necessity for providing a new residence for the Principal and male members of the staff of the Cross Lake Residential School.

The building which they are now occupying was built several years ago and has reached such a stage that it is impossible to properly repair it.

After consulting with the Principal of Cross Lake, Bishop Lajeunesse states that he considers a suitable building could be erected for $5000.00. He requests the Department provide half of this amount, or $2500.00, which would provide the materials needed, and the Bishop himself will provide the other half, covering the cost of the labour and any material that could not be purchased from the amount allowed by the Department.

I feel you will agree with me that it is most important to have proper housing accommodation for the Principal and male staff at the Cross Lake School and I feel that the Bishop's request is a very reasonable one. He is prepared to arrange purchase of the material at the lowest cost and forward to the Department receipted accounts for the amount of $2500.00. I trust that your Branch will find it possible to provide the funds immediately for the purpose mentioned above.

Yours truly,

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL.

Re: Cross Lake Indian Residential School.

I am sending forward herewith a letter received from the Reverend Father J. O. Plourde, O.M.I., the subject matter of which, you will note, is self-explanatory.

The records indicate that the Cross Lake Residential School was totally destroyed by fire in the year 1930 and rebuilt during the fiscal year 1938-39. It would appear, however, that no provision has been made at any time for the construction of a residence suitable for the principal and the male members of the staff.

The desirability of providing additional accommodation for the principal of the school and for the pupils in attendance at Cross Lake was discussed very fully with me by Dr. Corrigan when he visited this Branch a few weeks ago. In this connection may I refer you to a letter received from Dr. A. Corrigan, dated July 6, 1943 - File 123-1-1A. The Cross Lake School had at this date an authorized enrolment of 130, for which per capita grants were paid at the rate of $175.00. Dr. Corrigan was emphatic in his belief, however, that this enrolment should be substantially reduced. In response to the representations made to us by Dr. Corrigan at that time, the enrolment at the school was reduced from 100 to 60 pupils - see letter to Bishop Lajeunesse, dated July 13, 1943. Dr. Corrigan described the residence now occupied by the principal and certain male members of the staff as a dilapidated, insanitary shack. He pointed out
that inasmuch as no provision could be made for the accommodation of the principal in the school building itself, a principal's residence and one sufficiently large to accommodate all male members of the staff should be built by the Department at the earliest possible date.

While no provision has been made in the estimates of this year for the construction of such a building, it is just possible that should it be deemed advisable to proceed with the establishment of a principal's residence, funds might be secured by the transfer of the amount of $500.00 from the amount voted for the construction of schools and teachers' residences at the Shubenacadie and Eskasoni reserves in Nova Scotia.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Attention: Mr. R. A. Hoey.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Since writing to you on September 15th last, I received another letter from His Excellency Bishop Lajeunesse concerning the proposed residence for the Principal of the Cross Lake Indian Residential School.

This letter was written after receiving from Reverend Father Trudeau, the Principal of Gross Lake, further information regarding the approximate cost of this new residence. As a consequence, Bishop Lajeunesse informs me, and he wishes that the information be conveyed to the Department, that it will be impossible to erect a proper home and residence for the male staff of Cross Lake, for less than $7,000. Materials have increased so much in price, and labour, at least such as will have to be imported from Winnipeg, will cost in most cases twice what it would have before the war.

Whilst it is the Bishop's desire that most of the work be done by local mechanics, the electrical installation, the heating plant, the plastering, all items which must be figured at Winnipeg City prices, plus transportation, both ways, and even the payment of wages whilst the mechanics are travelling.

In view of the above, I am advised to ask for the sum of $3,500.

If you have not as yet written your memorandum to the Minister's office, I hope that you will enclose the above amount instead of that which I mentioned in my letter of September 15th last.

Attention: Mr. R. A. Hoey.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Since writing to you on September 15th last, I received another letter from His Excellency Bishop Lajeunesse concerning the proposed residence for the Principal of the Cross Lake Indian Residential School.

This letter was written after receiving from Reverend Father Trudeau, the Principal of Cross Lake, further information regarding the approximate cost of this new residence. As a consequence, Bishop Lajeunesse informs me, and he wishes that the information be conveyed to the Department, that it will be impossible to erect a proper home and residence for the male staff of Cross Lake for less than $7,000. Materials have increased so much in price, and labour, at least such as will have to be imported from Winnipeg, will cost in most cases twice what it would have before the war.

Whilst it is the Bishop's desire that most of the work be done by local mechanics, the electrical installation, the heating plant, the plastering, all items which must be figured at Winnipeg City prices, plus transportation, both ways, and even the payment of wages whilst the mechanics are travelling.

In view of the above, I am advised to ask for the sum of $3,500.

If you have not as yet written your memorandum to the Minister's office, I hope that you will enclose the above amount instead of that which I mentioned in my letter of September 15th last.

Thanking you in advance for your sympathetic consideration of this request, I remain,

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL.

Re: Cross Lake Indian Residential School.

I am sending forward herewith a letter received from the Reverend Father J. O. Plourde, O.M.I., the subject matter of which, you will note, is self-explanatory.

The records indicate that the Cross Lake Residential School was totally destroyed by fire in the year 1930 and rebuilt during the fiscal year 1938-39. It would appear, however, that no provision has been made at any time for the construction of a residence suitable for the principal and the male members of the staff.

The desirability of providing additional accommodation for the principal of the school and for the pupils in attendance at Cross Lake was discussed very fully with me by Dr. Corrigan when he visited this Branch a few weeks ago. In this connection may I refer you to a letter received from Dr. A. Corrigan, dated July 6, 1943 - File 123-1-1A. The Cross Lake School had at this date an authorized enrolment of 130, for which per capita grants were paid at the rate of $175.00. Dr. Corrigan was emphatic in his belief, however, that this enrolment should be substantially reduced. In response to the representations made to us by Dr. Corrigan at that time, the enrolment at the school was reduced from 100 to 80 pupils - see letter to Bishop Lajeunesse, dated July 13, 1943. Dr. Corrigan described the residence now occupied by the principal and certain male members of the staff as a dilapidated, insanitary shack. He pointed out
that inasmuch as no provision could be made for the accommodation of the principal in the school building itself, a principal's residence and one sufficiently large to accommodate all male members of the staff should be built by the Department at the earliest possible date.

While no provision has been made in the estimates of this year for the construction of such a building, it is just possible that should it be deemed advisable to proceed with the establishment of a principal's residence, funds might be secured by the transfer of the amount of $2500.00 from the amount voted for the construction of schools and teachers' residences at the Shubenacadie and Eskasoni reserves in Nova Scotia.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, September 15, 1943.

Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I am in receipt of a letter from Right Reverend M. Lajeunesse, O.M.I., Vicar-Apostolic of Keesatin, pointing out the necessity for providing a new residence for the Principal and male members of the staff of the Cross Lake Residential School.

The building which they are now occupying was built several years ago and has reached such a stage that it is impossible to properly repair it.

After consulting with the Principal of Cross Lake, Bishop Lajeunesse states that he considers a suitable building could be erected for $5000.00. He requests the Department provide half of this amount, or $2500.00, which would provide the materials needed, and the Bishop himself will provide the other half, covering the cost of the labour and any material that could not be purchased from the amount allowed by the Department.

I feel you will agree with me that it is most important to have proper housing accommodation for the Principal and male staff at the Cross Lake School and I feel that the Bishop's request is a very reasonable one. He is prepared to arrange purchase of the material at the lowest cost and forward to the Department receipted accounts for the amount of $2500.00. I trust that your Branch will find it possible to provide the funds immediately for the purpose mentioned above.

Yours truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.
MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Minister,

Re: Cross Lake Residential School.

Mr. Hoey has submitted to me two memoranda dealing with the above noted, dated September 20 and September 24, respectively. These memoranda I am enclosing with copies of relevant correspondence from Father Plourde.

In forwarding you this information with Father Plourde's request I regret that I cannot recommend that this proposal be given favourable consideration at this time.

Our past experience of undertakings under arrangements similar to those proposed in this case has taught us that such schemes rarely turn out satisfactorily. Usually the cost exceeds the original estimate. Examples may be cited in the Berens River building, the Cross Lake school itself, the Sandy Bay school and the Kenora school.

Even if the methods suggested were acceptable I would still feel that a number of projects in connection with schools and other departmental buildings should receive first consideration. In the Schools Division there are a number of buildings urgently required and which should be proceeded with as soon as money, labour and material are available. Among these I shall cite only a few: day schools in Prince Edward Island and Nova Scotia; the replacement of the Caughnawaga senior school which was destroyed by fire nearly two years ago; the Caughnawaga teachers' residence; the replacement of the classroom building at File Hills and also at Alberni which were completely destroyed by fire.

The best example to illustrate the point under discussion is one affecting the Cross Lake Reserve itself. The day school on this reserve under the auspices of the United Church was burned a year ago and has not yet been replaced.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

On January th twelfth I wire you from here asking you the permission to buy a new set of tubes for our High Pressure Boiler as why I was here on a business trip I received a Radiogram from Cross Lake that twelve tubes were leaking on our boiler. As I have not received any answer to my telegram I discuss the matter with Right Reverend Bishop Lajeunesse and we decided to buy them before receiving the authorization from you as it is urgent. The high pressure boiler is needed every week in the school for the washing. Also there is only one train a week to Wabowden which is the closest railway station from the school and a longer delay would put us in a critical condition at the school.

We had to order a complete set (75 tubes) as when they start to leak they have to be renewed entirely.

So I do hope that the Dept. will agree to pay this extra expense.

I beg to report that during my visit to the Cross Lake Reserve, during the week of January 22nd last, I inspected the Cross Lake R.C. Indian residential School, and spent a full half day in each of the three class rooms.

In the Junior class room, where the Grade 1 and 'Beginners' pupils were, there were 32 pupils present - 17-boys and 15-girls. The work of these pupils was very creditable. Their reading aloud was quite good; also simple arithmetic on the blackboard, and spelling. Their book work too was good. All these pupils were clean and well clothed, and the discipline was very good. The teacher was keenly interested in her work. All the class room furniture of every kind was in excellent condition. The register was marked up to date.

In the boys room there were four grades being taught - grades 2, 3, 4, and 5. There were 30 boys present, all clean and well clothed and tidy in every respect. The work of these boys was very good in every way; reading, spelling, book work, and blackboard work. The discipline was very good, and the teacher well qualified for her work and showing great interest in it. The class room and all its furnishings were in excellent condition. The register was marked up to date.

In the girls room, there were pupils in six grades, from grade 2 to grade 7 inclusive, there being a total of 34 girls present. All these girls were doing very good work and showing interest. Their book work was especially good being neat, clean, and accurate generally. The discipline was very good, and the teacher very interested and keen about her work. The register was marked up to date. The class room and furnishings were all in excellent condition, and all the pupils clean and well clothed.

There was a total of 96 pupils in residence in the school, and all 96 were in the class rooms, none being absent on account of sickness or any other cause.

The dormitories, dining rooms, kitchen, laundry, and all other departments of this school are kept in spotless condition. The high pressure steam boiler was not in operation as the flues had worn out, and a new set had been ordered from Winnipeg. The electric light and power plant at this school is entirely dependent upon one single 10 H.P. Diesel engine, and if for any reason this engine broke down considerable trouble would ensue. I asked to see what repair parts they had on hand for emergency, and found that there was practically nothing in this line. I therefore asked the Principal and the engineer to make up a list of repair parts immediately, which they did. This list is being forwarded to the Department in the form of a requisition, with a separate covering letter.

P.G. Lazenby, Indian Agent.

Attention Mr. Phelan.

My dear Mr. Phelan,

Enclosed please find receipted invoices and labour vouchers re the building of the Principal's residence at Cross Lake.

The amount authorized to be spent on this project was $3,500. Due to the high cost of labour, the increase in wages, and the freight rate from Winnipeg to Cross Lake, the cost of the building was $7,194.04, exclusive of the expense involved in installing the heating and plumbing which - by the way - was done by our own Brothers.

It is evident that had His Excellency Bishop Lajeunesse realized that he would be obliged to supply such a large amount out of his own meager resources, he would have either asked for a larger grant or waited until the end of the war before undertaking the erection of this building.

Cross Lake Indian Boarding School:

This school is situated in an isolated area and the Rev. Father is greatly concerned, and rightly so, about his one engine and generator. If the engine should fail at any time the school would be without light or water - in fact, it could not continue to operate. I think a second unit should be installed. There is plenty of room, consequently no additional expenses will be required for building purposes. The total cost would be for the engine, generator and wages for someone to see that it is properly installed. I think the Department should give this request serious consideration. If the school were close to a railroad I would not make the recommendation; but a bad break in equipment at this isolated point would be serious and perhaps repairs could not be secured for weeks. There are often weeks when communication to the outside is impossible and this is especially bad at freeze-up and again in the spring during break-up.

The hot water tank which hangs by the furnace also must be renewed. I understand Mr. Lazenby has the particulars and is submitting the necessary requisition. This should be ordered and sent forward at once.

Re: Lighting Plant for Cross Lake School.

Attention: Mr. P. Phelan.

My dear Mr. Phelan,

I am in receipt today, of a letter from Reverend Father G.E. Trudeau, O.M.I., Principal of the above school, regarding the necessity of the purchase of an auxiliary lighting plant.

Cross Lake is about 450 miles North of Winnipeg and can only be reached in the summer time when the boats are running. For at least eight months of the year, the place is inaccessible. The school being modern, the heating plant is partly operated by electricity, as there is a motor for pumping returns to the boiler and in case of a breakdown of the electrical plant, there would be no way of operating the heating plant with the consequence that everything in the school would freeze. The damage thus caused, would be so severe that everything must be done to prevent it.

I am informed that all the inspectors and agents that have visited the school, have commented adversely on this situation and have, at various times, requested your Department to supply an auxiliary electrical plant. Whilst the War was on, it was possibly difficult to purchase this plant but now that we are at peace with the wide world, such a plant should be secured immediately and installed during the coming summer months.

The batteries used in connection with

2.....
their plant are described as follows:

1 set of 56 (Volts) Batteries Type GD Capacity 200A.H.
Globelight Power Batteries Ser. No. 7656.

When Mr. Morris visited this school, he recommended that the attic of the school be finished with Tentest and used for the purpose and training both the boys and girls, in the various activities of the school and he told the Principal to get a price on the cost of the material and labour. Mr. P. Desrosiers, St-Boniface contractor, has estimated the work and material to be worth $1200.00 and Father Trudeau kindly requests that this be provided for, in next year's estimates.

Yours very truly,

I have just returned from Cross Lake where I spent a week. I inspected the St Joseph's R.C. Residential School and was greatly impressed by the work that is being done in this institution. I inspected both the school and the building.

The oven for baking bread, which they have at present is too small and out of proportion to the capacity of the mixer. Father Trudeau requested that I try and obtain, for him another oven, i.e.; Economy Oven patented trade mark registered No 3-Serial 1066 -5' by 4' of the Jean Daoust Co of St Boniface, Man.

I strongly recommend that this request be granted as I believe it would be a saving of labor and fuel and would be productive of better bread.

Dear Sir,

Could you possibly obtain for our School a good piano.

Of course, we understand that this is an unusual petition, but we feel that a piano is a necessary instrument in a school, not only for the recreational purpose of the pupils, but also for their educational welfare.

The kind interest and sympathy you have shown our little Indian people give us the hope that you'll take our request in consideration and oblige.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept' of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I recently spent a week on the Cross Lake Reservation. I visited homes on the Reservation, gave pep talks to the President of the women's home-makers clubs and inspected both Schools, which are both doing very well.

I stayed at the R.C. St Joseph's Residential School and was very impressed with the excellent work that is being done here. I attended their Christmas concert and noticed that they have considerable musical talent, both on the staff and among the pupils. The only instrument they have for teaching music is an ancient piano which is hideously out of tune. I understand from Father Trudeau that it is impossible to tune it, as the pegs which hold the wires are worn in their sockets and slip and lose tension. I strongly recommend that for the good of the work being done, that they be provided with a new instrument.

There is in the city of Glasgow, Scotland, a firm which manufactures a species of piano known as a 'Dulcitone'. It has all the attributes of a piano but instead of wires which need constant tuning, tuning forks are used. This instrument is compact, light, and easily portable and never requires tuning. It was built especially for the tropics. It seems to me that it is the ideal instrument for Northern isolated schools like Cross Lake. The cost as I remember it, was in the neighborhood of about $300.00 but I am not sure. You may be able to ascertain the name of the firm through a trade commissioner. In the meantime I have written to the London Daily Mail-England, who used to carry the advertisement for this instrument in their overseas edition and it is some years since I have seen it.

E.B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.

IMPORTANT FACTORS WHICH SHOULD BE TAKEN INTO CONSIDERATION IN SELECTING AN ENGINE.

HORSE POWER AND GOVERNOR SPEED at which Engine is to be operated. Variable Speed Control Fitting can be supplied as an extra.

ROTATION—Engines will be supplied with Rotation Clockwise looking on Flywheel with Fuel Pump on right hand side.

COOLING—State whether the Engine is required for Temperate or Tropical Climate and whether Tank or Radiator cooling system is required. State whether load is continuous or intermittent.

AIR CLEANERS—Engines to be operated under Dusty or Gritty conditions should always be fitted with efficient Air Cleaning equipment. A Lister Air Cleaner is suitable for average dirty conditions, or an Air Cleaner of the Vortox type for more severe conditions where abrasive dust is present. Please see separate page on this subject and state requirements when ordering.

GENERAL CONDITIONS—The following allowances should be made when estimating nett H.P. required.

ALTITUDE—A reduction of 4% per 1,000 ft. above 330 ft. above sea level.

TEMPERATURE—A reduction of 1% for every 5ºF over 65ºF.

INSTALLATION—Particulars of Engine mounting and type of Drive should be stated wherever possible. When a special Exhaust pipe layout is to be used please consult us and give us as much information as possible.
DESCRIPTION OF ENGINE

THE ENGINE is provided with a specially designed Combustion Head incorporating the "Lister Patent Combustion Chamber," which ensures a positive start from cold by hand without need of Cartridge, Heating Lamp or Electric ignition. A variable compression ratio initially ensures easy starting and subsequent running at low maximum pressures.

THE CYLINDER LINER is treated with the process of chrome hardening (Van der Horst Patents) which has been proved to give the greatest wear resisting surface yet known, whether the wear may be due to heat, chemical action or abrasion from the piston rings; thus giving a greatly lengthened life throughout which the engine retains its ease of starting, fuel and lubricating oil consumption, and develops rated power.

THE PISTONS AND RINGS are of high grade material, and finished to an accuracy equal to that employed in the finest motor car engines, long life and full compression are thus assured.

THE CRANKCASE is totally enclosed and dust proof, making the engine especially suitable for work in dusty and gritty surroundings.

THE CRANKSHAFT is made from high grade steel, accurately machined and finished by grinding to an accuracy of half of one thousandth of an inch.

THE CAMS, CAMSHAFT AND ROCKERS are of high grade steel, accurately machined. The working parts hardened and finished by grinding.

THE CONNECTING ROD is a Steel forging with renewable Phosphor Bronze Bush at small end, and the large end Bearing is bronze shell white metal lined.

THE BEARINGS for Crankshaft are of ample size to provide maximum durability.

THE VALVES are of the finest alloy heat resisting steel, and the valve seatings are efficiently water cooled for increased life.

FUEL PUMP & FUEL INJECTOR C.A.V. Bosch Fuel Pumps and suitable Fuel Injectors are fitted.

GOVERNOR is of the centrifugal type and operates on the fuel injection pump, varying the quantity of fuel injected in accordance with the load.

LUBRICATION is automatic. Main Camshaft and Fuel Pump drive gear bearings are fed by pump. Splash and Oil mist from Big End lubricates all other parts.

GENERAL EQUIPMENT Tank or radiator to suit requirements. Exhaust Silencer, Air Silencer, Fuel Tank and piping, Starting Handle, Set of Tools and Funnel with Strainer where necessary. Tank Cooled Engines ordered without Water Cooling Tanks are supplied with water connections unless contrary instructions are given. Where Radiator cooling is supplied an allowance of \( \frac{1}{4} \) h.p. should be made for fan.

Attention: Mr. P. Phelan.
Re: Repairs to Kitchen Sinks for the Grass Lake Guy, Beauval and Duck Lake Indian Residential Schools.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

During the course of my summer visits to the above schools I noticed that all kitchen sinks were in bad condition and should be repaired as soon as possible. Monel Metal or Stainless Steel are the most economical metals to use for such work.

The J.R. Douglas Company Limited, 262 Slater Street, Ottawa, have both Stainless Steel and Monel Metal sheets for sale and can supply them on request. According to gage, the price varies from one dollar and twenty-five to one seventy-five per square foot. I figure that four sheets of either metal would be sufficient for making these repairs in each of the above schools. It would therefore be very much appreciated if you would place an order for either metal immediately with the Douglas Company. I may add that I could not find Stainless Steel or Monel Metal in either Edmonton, Regina or Winnipeg; that is why I am giving you the name of the J.R. Douglas Company Limited.

Thanking you in anticipation,

I remain,

Yours very truly,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

In reply to yours of September the 16th received yesterday, I must say that I have no quotations for the Servel Kerosene Refrigerator. As Mr. Waite is not at Norway House and having seen him only once in August I cannot tell you if he had any quotation from Servel.

When Mr. Waite was here for paying treaty in June I made the requisition for a Kerosene Refrigerator and I had told him that our electric plan would not be strong enough to carry extra load as we were already using more electricity than we could produce. I told Mr. Waite that we needed a big kerosene refrigerator as those they use in restaurants and I doubt that one of 7 cubic feet would meet our needs. It would take at least an 8 cubic feet one or even larger one but not an electric one.

As the navigation season will be closed in two or three weeks I am afraid that it could not be sent by boat but would have to be sent by Railrod Freight Via Wabowden, Manitoba and we could bring it to the school by tractor in December.

Ottawa, March 4, 1913.

Sir,

Referring to the recent telegram sent you yesterday I beg to say that, as plans and specifications for the proposed Roman Catholic Boarding School at Norway House are under preparation and as it is desired to proceed with building operations, if possible, next summer, the matter of site must be decided upon without delay.

In the first place the Church was to assume the cost of building and the securing of the site, of course, rested with them. Now the Department has undertaken the obligation and before work can be commenced the question of site, title of which must rest in the Crown, arises. A site on the reserve somewhat near the present Roman Catholic property, if the band in council would give consent, would obviate all difficulties. If this is not possible other steps will have to be taken. The Roman Catholic Church some time ago applied for a patent for lot 6, not far from the Hudson Bay Co.'s post and formerly owned by Charles Creight. Copies of all correspondence in connection therewith are enclosed, as well as a blue print showing the location of the lot; also blue print of the reserve as constituted now, showing position of the Roman Catholic mission property on Fort Island. It should be possible to obtain and transmit here the information asked for by the Interior Department, as called for in letter of May 6, 1912, addressed to J. R. Bunn, Esq., Inspector of Indian Agencies, Winnipeg, Man.

Sir,

As the Revd Father Lecq will probably be away to Winnipeg for an indefinite time, I had an interview with the Revd Father Thomas, who is his assistant, in connection with the site of the new R.C. Boarding School.

Revd Father Thomas and myself discussed the site of the new school fully. In his statement to me he said that the site chosen was about ½ of a mile south of the Hudson's Bay Trading Post on the Nelson River.

After making careful investigations as to a site for their new Boarding school along the Jack River and the Nelson River, they finally selected this place as being a good site. The principal objection they had to Jack river was rock, and as the river is very grassy it makes it impossible to use a Tug steamer in connection with their school. This Tug steam-boat which they are about to build is to be used in the transportation of the building material for their school and also for freighting the yearly supplies afterwards.

The site chosen was selected on account of there being no rock to contend with in the making of the Basement for the school and mostly on account of the splendid sewage facilities and the laying of a pipe to the river for clean water for the use of the school. There is also a quantity of good land for a large garden which they contemplate using, so as to give the pupils instructions in gardening and the raising of all kinds of vegetables, which ought to be very useful to the pupils in future.

I don't think that a better site could have been chosen, as it is in the direct way of travel from all parts of the Agency, and principally for the drainage.
drainage.

and sewerage which is of the best, as the river has a good current, and will naturally carry off all sewerage filth from the vicinity of those living between the school and the little Play-Green Lake. I have marked the place chosen for a site on the map by a X in black ink as carefully as I could.

On the property chosen, an Indian of the name of Amos Colon was living, and the Revd Father Lecoq paid him for all rights and improvements he had. This land belongs to the Crown, and Father Thomas says that they have no wish to own the land, but would like that they be refunded the money paid to this man in order to secure this site. The amount paid was $150.00.

Amos Colon is a Treaty man and had no rights to the land, as he should have been on the reserve, but I understand that this place has been in his family for a long time, and he has lived for a number of years on this place, so I think the amount paid him was a just payment as he will have to remove his house to the Reserve now.

"We have been informed that the Dominion lands are soon to be transferred to the provinces and we have also been told that, if we intend to apply for lands to be used in connection with our School, we had better do so at the earliest date possible. After consultation with Mr. Waddy, His Lordship Bishop Charlebois advised me to ask you to submit our request to the Department.

In the map which is hereto attached No. 1 represents the location of the Cross Lake Indian School. No. 2 is the school land on which we have been cutting construction and cord wood for a number of years. It is now almost exhausted, and, on account of numerous marshes and patches of bare rock, cannot be used for farming purposes. No. 3 shows the place where we wish to obtain a section for cutting cord wood. This section would be adjacent to the land which we now own; it would not be far from the School and could furnish fuel wood for many years to come. At No. 4 we would like to get a section for farming. We began farming operations there last year and we have now 35 acres under cultivation.

Should the Department think that we do not need all the land we are asking for, we might put forward the following considerations:

1. More than one half of the land of these regions consists of marshes and bare rocks which can be of no use whatever.
2. About 400 cords of wood are needed yearly for the School. Should we fail to obtain the section No. 3 (on map) this large quantity of wood would have to be transported at heavy cost from great distances.
3. Mining companies intend to build a dam on the outlet of Cross Lake in order to develop electric power. This dam will raise the level of the lake and drown the natural meadows on which we have cut hay for our cattle in past years. This..."
This will necessitate the clearing of land for pasture and the raising of hay.

We therefore ask the Department to obtain for the use of the Cross Lake Indian School the sections marked (3) and (4) on the accompanying map.

Mr. R.T. Ferrier has kindly promised that he would attend to this request and I feel confident that the matter will be brought to a successful issue.

Cross Lake, Dec. 21, 1938.

Re: Cross Lake-Wabowden Road.

Honourable Sir:

The work proposed for this year on our Residential School is practically completed. The walls have been built up and the building closed. Though the expenses exceed considerably the grant allowed for, I feel confident you will not be deceived, as you have seen the conditions of the building and the size of it. If we keep in mind the distances and difficulties for transport, the late season in which the work had to be carried on, I think we should feel satisfied at the amount of work done.

We have appreciated your kind cooperation and feel much obliged to you.

I have to state it has not only been preparation for the future welfare of the Indians, but also a very important and very needed help for the Indians of this reserve. Their condition would have been at worst had not this construction started on. It has meant for them a decent living last fall and for the first part of the winter. In as much as we could, we have endeavoured to give a chance of earning to everyone of this settlement. I should say it has been their salvation. The prospects for fur were so poor that the traders did not care to give out a nickel in debt.

Now the trapping season is opened and the forecasts have come to reality: fur is very scarce and prices for most of the furs are low. It is easy to foresee poverty for the severe part of the winter: January and February, which is always a very poor trapping time.

Having this in mind and considering the real need we have of a suitable road to the railway station, Wabowden on H.B. Ry., I wish to recommend this work to your attention and ask for a grant of about two thousand ($2,000.) dollars to have this road cut and improved.

The necessity of this road is undoubted. During the winter months, it is the only way of communication with outside. Although the important amount of freight comes by boat, every winter there is always a fair quantity coming over this road. This winter especially on account of the construction, over sixty tone will have to be taken in this way. Furthermore, many of the trappers take their fur up to Wabowden where they get far better prices for them and pay less for the goods they buy. There is lots of traffic on this road. One point that needs consideration is the mail service we are requesting to be done by horses or dogs. It was giving better
accommodation than the air mail service and was costing less. We ask to come back to the old way, which was the best for this settlement.

The actual road is but a trapper's path which leads through muskegs, creeks, hills and is in no way proper for freighting and travelling with horses. The proposed road would be more level, more sheltered and shorter by at least eight to ten miles.

The road we are asking for has been cut for about half way. With the grant we request, the cutting could be completed and the road improved and opened for transport.

The Provincial Government has already been asked for a grant. I am sure they will agree to cooperate.

Mr. P. Sutherland is well aware about this road and could give you other particulars if necessary.

I take the opportunity to recommend for the success of the Day School the corduroying of a swamp between the school and the reserve. When children can not come by canoe, they are prevented to come to school on account of this swamp and two creeks at each side of it. Two bridges would have to be erected and the swamp corduroied.

I suggest you these works as I sincerely think that help will have to be given to the Indians this winter. I trust this will meet your approval and be granted if any money is available at the present.

Re: Muskrat Farms.

Last summer in the short talk we had during your very pleasant visit, I had told you about the necessity of muskrats farms. I heartily believe that it is time to make steps forward in this direction. Undoubtedly there will be difficulties to establish them, but at any rate they should be undertaken if we want to assure to our Indians a living.

On the land owned by the Res. School, there are some creeks. I will try to convince the Indians not to trap the muskrats there. This experiment will give us an idea of how much they can increase when they are left alone.

With my sincere thanks for your devotedness to the Indians Affairs, receive my heartfelt wishes for a very Merry Christmas and joy, prosperity and success in your important and difficult office. May the Almighty bestow upon you and upon all those you care for His most precious blessings.

Yours sincerely,

(sgd.) Albert Chamberland, O.M.I.
Principal.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER:

Re: $2,000 grant for road, Cross Lake - Wabowden; corduroying swamp from reserve to school; and re muskrat farms.

Reverend Albert Chamberland, O.M.I., Principal of the Indian Residential School at Cross Lake, Manitoba, in a letter to the Minister dated December 29, 1938, asks among other things for a grant of approximately $2,000.00 for the construction of a winter road between the school at Cross Lake and Wabowden, a station on the Hudson Bay Railway, a distance of approximately 45 miles.

Father Chamberland intimates in his communication that the major portion of his freight and the supplies necessary for the operation of the residential school have been reaching the institution by boat. The officials of this Branch are of the opinion that this is the most inexpensive and satisfactory method of transporting freight to the Cross Lake School. The Principal is of the opinion however that the road should be constructed as a mail route and as a transportation route that would enable the trappers of the district to secure a better price for their furs when delivered at Wabowden. The Principal estimates that at least 60 tons of supplies necessary for the rebuilding of the Cross Lake School will pass over the route this winter. It is not at all likely however that a grant, if made now, could be utilized in time to reconstruct the road for transportation of the goods necessary for the building of the school.

In view of these facts, it is difficult to see how the -
how the suggested grant of $2,000 could be legitimately charged to any of the appropriations of this Branch. It has not been at any time the policy of the Department to pay for the construction of roads on lands other than those within actual boundaries of Indian reserves.

Father Chamberland suggests the corduroying of the swamp between the school and the Indian reserve. This is a project that might be undertaken by the Indians now in receipt of relief at Cross Lake. If you so desire, I shall be glad to communicate with the Indian Agent with the object of having this work undertaken by the Indians, on the understanding that the project is to be completed in return for rations supplied by the Department.

Father Chamberland refers to a conversation he had with the Minister last summer, relating to the development of muskrat areas in the district. You are probably aware that we are at present negotiating with the Provincial Government in an attempt to secure an area of approximately 10,000 acres in the Cross Lake district for the use of Indians. It is in my judgment useless to talk of the development of muskrat areas at Cross Lake or the conservation of fur life in the district until an understanding has been reached with the Provincial Government in respect to the lands now under consideration. It is our intention, however, to continue these negotiations until a settlement measurably satisfactory to all parties is reached.

Mr. Halcrow made a survey of the Cross Lake district about a year ago with the object of determining the possibilities of the area for muskrat development. His report containing certain specific recommendations is now in possession of this Branch.

I am returning herewith Father Chamberland's letter.

Director.

Sir:

It will be remembered that, after the burning of St. Joseph's residential school at Cross Lake, some eleven boys were transferred temporarily to the R.C. Mission at Norway House. These boys have now gone home to Island Lake and God's Lake for the vacation. There is no doubt that at Treaty time some of the parents will declare that they sent their children to Cross Lake, and as that school is not now carrying on as a residential school, their arrangement is cancelled, since the school at Norway House is not a Residential school. Shall I insist positively that the children must be returned to school at the end of the vacation? I would recommend that this be done, with the exception of those whose discharge I have already recommended.

I may say that the representative of the Provincial Board of Health stated to me that the R.C. Mission at Norway House had accommodation for sixteen boarders only, should not exceed that number. Of course the putting of these children at that Institution was an emergency measure. During the past quarter there have been in excess of twenty in residence, there being, besides the eleven from St. Joseph's school, a number of half-breeds, and some Indian children of Norway House Band as well. In view of these facts, I would suggest that no more children be taken in under Government grant than those already there.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir:

I am enclosing an Application for Admission to Cross Lake, (St. Joseph's) Residential School from Edward Mason of Island Lake, for his son James Mason, aged ten years.

It is a little difficult to know just what to do with such an application. The school is, of course, unable to accept residence pupils. There are several boys, former pupils of this school, who are in attendance at the Day School at the R.C. Mission on Jack River, at Norway House, and some arrangement I presume, has been arrived at as to payment for these pupils through the St. Joseph's School. It may be that this boy could be accepted as a pupil of St. Joseph's school, and temporarily lodged and taught at Norway House R.C. Mission.

The mother of the boy is an invalid. The family are in poor circumstances, as the father is unable to go away from home to trap during the winter. The boy would be better where he would receive regular food, and should be in school of course. On the other hand, I am quite sure that the number of children lodged at the R.C. # 098 Flora McKay .... 15 years
# 010 Charlotte North .... 15 years
# 075 Veronique Cook .... 14 years

All the others are under 14 years.

I take advantage of this occasion to ask you also to please discharge No. 010 Rena Frogg. She was taken home by her mother a few months ago, during my absence, for unfounded, light reasons in regards to menstruation. It has been impossible for me to make her return. Our reason for desiring her discharge is because she was a continual cause of trouble and her conduct gave bad example to the others. She is 15 years old and is in the 11th Grade. Since, you see, her term at school is nearly finished, we do not see any great inconvenience in discharging her.

Ottawa, July 5, 1934.

Rev. Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 21st ultimo, I beg to say that the discharge of Rena Frogg, No. 0110, from the Cross Lake Indian Residential School is approved.

It is noted that there are no children in the Cross Lake School who are over sixteen years of age.

As I presume you have already noted, the Department is not insisting on the discharge of pupils when they reach the age of sixteen years. The circular letter pointed out that, when pupils reach this age and you wish to keep them for a further period, permission should be secured. Consequently, at the end of each academic year in future, you should forward to the Department, through the office of your local Indian Agent, a list giving the names and register numbers of all pupils sixteen years of age and over. In the case of those whom you desire to keep for a further period, you should request permission to do so, giving your reasons for this request.

Your obedient servant,

Philip Phelan,
For Supt. of Indian Education.

Sir,-

Madeleine Wood
Nancy Maskego
Solomon Chubb
Frederick Duck
Boniface Okimew

The Department understands that some of the children are at Cross Lake Mission and the remainder are at the Roman Catholic Mission at Norway House. Grant is provided for a total of thirty (30) children at both places. Only one quarterly return, including the names of all the children, should be forwarded to the Department.

It is further understood that, in placing children in the Roman Catholic Mission at Norway House, the same regulations will apply as in the case of any other Indian residential school. Only Roman Catholic children should be admitted and application forms and certificates of health for all new pupils should be forwarded for the Department's consideration. Applicants should be Treaty Indian children. No discharges should be granted without securing the Department's consent. The Indian Agent and any other departmental official may visit and inspect the accommodation used by the children at any time.

Right Reverend Sir:

Referring to conversation with Your Lordship during your recent visit to the Department, regarding the age limit for the discharge of the boys who are 14 years of age from the residential schools conducted under your auspices, in order that they can be returned to their parents, to acquire a knowledge of hunting, trapping etc., I have to say that this meets with the approval of the Department. The Indian Agents at The Pas, Norway House, and Battleford are being informed and requested to advise the Principals of the Guy, Cross Lake and Beauval Indian Residential Schools accordingly.

It is not intended that all the boys, upon attaining 14 years of age, shall be granted discharge, but only those cases which the Principals consider to be in sufficiently good health to accompany their parents on their hunting and trapping trips. It is thought that Indian boys should have acquired sufficient education for their future needs by the time they reach 14 years of age and that it would be to their future advantage to acquire a knowledge of hunting and trapping, on which their future livelihood will, to a great extent, depend.

I would suggest that Your Lordship discuss the matter with the Principals of the above named schools and advise them that careful selection should be made by them of the boys whose discharge they would recommend at 14 years of age.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.
