Ottawa, April 14, 1936.

Dear Sir:

His Lordship Bishop Lajeunesse, during a recent visit to the Department, discussed the matter of the age limit for the discharge of the boys from the Indian Residential Schools conducted under his auspices. He recommended that those boys who are in good health should be given their discharge when they reach 14 years of age, in order that they can be returned to their parents or guardians, with a view to acquiring a knowledge of hunting and trapping, which will be the main source of their future livelihood.

The Department considers that it would be in the interests of the boys to be granted their discharge at 14 years of age, as they should by that time have acquired an education sufficient to meet their future needs. You may, therefore, inform the Principal of the Cross Lake Indian Residential School that, when he considers that a boy, upon attaining his fourteenth birthday, should receive his discharge, he should make application to the Department, through your office, in the usual manner.

It is not intended that all boys, upon reaching 14 years of age, are to be discharged, but, as stated, only those who are in sufficiently healthy condition to accompany their parents or guardians in order to acquire a knowledge of hunting, trapping, etc.

I would request that you advise the Principal accordingly.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Adam Dixon.

Mon cher Père,

Ci-inclus copie d'une lettre du R. P. Boissin ainsi que d'autres documents ayant trait au refus du Département Indien d'admettre Henrietta et Nancy Dixon à l'Ecole Catholique Résidentielle de Cross Lake, sous prétexte que ces deux enfants ont été baptisées et élevées dans la religion protestante. (Lettre agent, 27 déc.)

Si vous vous rappelez bien, à la dernière réunion du comité des missions, il a été question de cas semblables, et il a été décidé qu'on s'en tiendrait aux décisions légales données antérieurement et qui veulent que la volonté des parents soit souveraine quand il s'agit de l'éducation religieuse de leurs enfants. Qu'un enfant ait été baptisé et élevé catholique ou protestant cela n'y fait rien si les parents décident de la placer dans une école de leur choix.

C'est d'ailleurs la ligne de conduite suivie par le Département, et de cela nous avons des preuves multiples. Je m'en citerai que quatre.

1) Catherine Sinclair fille d'Albert Sinclair de Cross Lake, baptisée catholique dès l'enfance et ayant fréquenté l'école pensionnat de Cross Lake durant deux ans avant le feu, et l'école du jour catholique au moins une année après le feu, a bel et bien été admise à l'Ecole protestante de Norway House. Elle doit être maintenant déchargée.

2) La fille de William Thomas, autrefois de Cross Lake et maintenant de Nelson House a été admise l'an dernier à l'école protestante de Brandon. Elle y est encore probablement. Or étant nébe elle a été baptisée catholique et est supposée avoir été élevée catholique.
3 et 4) Qu'on consulte encore les registres de l'Ecole Protestante de Norway-House et on y verra les noms d'Oliver Sinclair fils de Charlie Sinclair de Cross Lake, et Marguerite MacKay fille d'Edouard MacKay, deux enfants qui ont été baptisés et élevés catholiques.

Je suppose qu'il n'y a pas deux poids et deux mesures au Département. Si la volonté des parents vaut dans un cas elle doit aussi valoir dans l'autre. Or ici la volonté du Père des enfants Henrietta et Nancy est bien expresse comme on peut le voir par l'affidavit ci-inclus. Vous pouvez dire au Département que dans les circonstances présentes, le renvoi des enfants Henrietta et Nancy Dixon constituerait à notre endroit un deni de justice.

Je vous pris d'agir le plus tôt possible et de ne rien négliger pour assurer le règlement favorable de cette question.

Veuillez croire, mon Révérend et cher Père, à mes sentiments respectueux et dévoués en N.-S. et M. I.

"Martin Lajeunesse, O.M.I."
Vicaire Apostolique du Keewatin

My dear Mr. Phelan:

In a letter dated December 12, 1938, your Indian Agent at Norway House, Mr. P. G. Lezenby, approved the admission of Nancy and Henrietta Dixon to the Cross Lake Indian Residential School but, in a communication dated December 27, 1938, he informed the Principal that he had received instructions from Ottawa to the effect that Nancy and Henrietta Dixon having been baptized and brought up as protestants were not eligible for admission to the Cross Lake Indian Residential School and were to be returned to their father at the earliest possible date.

On receipt of this letter from Mr. Lezenby, Father Boissin interviewed the father of the Dixon children and asked him if it was his desire that his children be dismissed from the Cross Lake Residential School and returned to him. Adam Dixon then stated that it was his express wish that his children be kept in the Cross Lake School. He then made the enclosed declaration before Mr. Jack Wright, the Police Magistrate for the District of Norway House.

It being the will of Adam Dixon that his children be educated in a Catholic School, Bishop Lajeunesse informs me that he cannot accept the decision of the Department, his claim being that the will of the parents in matters of education is supreme and recognized as such in an opinion given by the Department of Justice on January 5, 1922. You are no doubt acquainted with this opinion and I need not quote it here; it will be found in a letter written by Mr. D. C. Scott to Mr. Bunn on October 16, 1922. I am enclosing a copy of Bishop Lajeunesse's letter to me bearing on this case and dated the 13th instant.

Yours very truly,

JOP/TR

So as these children belong to the Norway House Agency, I am asking that the admission of these children should be granted for St. Joseph's Indian Residential School, Cross Lake, Manitoba, where the children are being sent on the request of the Indian Agent of The Pas, Manitoba.

Dear Sir,

I must inform you about one of our pupils named George Menow the son of Johnnie Menow - We are unable to keep him any more. He is going away home all the time. We can't tie him up we have to let him go out for recreation. As soon as he is outside he is flying away - Once the police brought him back and told next time you are going away I put you in the prison. But he is scare of nobody. This boy is not intelligent at all. The sisters and me thing that he will never know anything about teaching. If you think so we could discharge him or send him to Cross Lake school.

Yours very truly,

(S'gd) Rev: H.Boissin O.M.I.

Norway House, Man:
26th October 1940.

Sir,

I beg to forward herewith the Principal's Return for the Cross Lake R.C. Residential School, for the quarter ending 30th September 1940.

With reference to the two Miller children, pupils No: 156, William Miller, and No: 0173 Jane Miller, the Principal advises me that he is having some difficulty in securing the Application forms for these children. They formerly lived with their parents at The Pas, until both parents died. They then spent some time in hospital at The Pas; were examined for admission to a residential school first without being approved by the medical examiner. Later they were passed by the doctor and their admission to Guy Residential School was approved. However they did not go to that school, but were brought to Cross Lake school, and up to the present time, no proper applications for Cross Lake School have been sent in. The Principal advises me that he has written to Father Trudeau at The Pas to get the necessary particulars and signatures on the application forms, and will then have the children examined by Dr Corrigan on his next trip to Cross Lake.

Your obedient Servant

P.G. Lazenby
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Re: Children of Albert Richard
No. 448 Cross Lake Band.

During Treaty payments at Cross Lake this year I was approached by Mr. A. E. Caldwell, Principal of the Norway House United Church Indian Residential School who requested a ruling in connection with the above noted.

Mr. Caldwell gave me a statement signed by Albert and Sarah Richard - copy of which is attached - and explained he had received an application from these people to have their sons William and Walter who are now pupils in the Cross Lake Roman Catholic Indian Residential School admitted to the Norway House United Church Indian Residential School.

The Principal of the Norway House School refused to accept applications for admittance of these children until a ruling from the Department was received.

Richard Albert states he has always been a Protestant. He married a Roman Catholic woman but he informed me she changed Faith and was accepted into the United Church at Cross Lake in 1933.

In 1938 the oldest child, Katie, now aged 12, was admitted to the Norway House School.

In 1940, William, now aged 11, was baptised into the Roman Catholic Church and admitted to the Cross Lake School, January 27th of that year.

On October 3rd, 1940, Walter, now aged 8, was admitted to the Cross Lake School.

I am, and always have been, Protestant, a member of the United Church of Canada. My wife was Catholic but was received into membership of the United Church of Canada in 1932. My wife and I have six children, three being of school age. In August, 1938, I placed one child (my oldest) in the Norway House Residential School. In 1940, I placed two children in the Cross Lake Roman Catholic School, having been sent for by the Principal and requested so to do at the Catholic School.

It is the wish of myself and my wife that our children should be raised in the Protestant Faith and attend a Protestant school. I hereby voluntarily make the request that my children, at present in the Cross Lake Roman Catholic School, be transferred immediately to the Norway House Residential School.

No inducement has been offered and no influence brought to bear by anyone connected with the Norway House Residential School or with the United Church of Canada to require me to make this request.

Dated at Cross Lake Indian Reserve this 11th day of August 1941.

Dear Sir:-

We have two girls in the School; Teresa Keeper and Harriet Ross who continually obst the discipline. They are both fourteen years old though you would think that they are sixteen. We don't know what to do with them and they won't listen to no one. We tried any thing to make them understand better but it seems useless. We certainly keep them any longer in the School as they corrupted the morals of the young girls and are spreading bad spirit in the school. I can not send them on the Reserve as they are orphans and nobody wants to keep them. We found a place in Winnipeg where they keep girls of that temper. They would accept these two girls at the same conditions that the Dept. pays for their children here and they would be ready to take them before the end of this month. Could you give us the permission to send them right away and would the Department be prepared to pay for them while they would be at the Good Shepherd until they will obtained the age of sixteen or eighteen.

I would appreciate to receive an early answer as the travelling will soon be difficult and I would not like to be oblige to keep these girls until next summer in the school.

Yours sincerely,

G.E.Trudeau, O.M.I.
Principal.

Please wire Mr. Lazenby instructions re these cases as soon as possible.

P.E.Moore
Ottawa,
March 19, 1942.

AIR MAIL

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant with reference to Teresa Keeper and Harriet Ross.

Very careful consideration has been given to the contents of your letter but the Department doubts the advisability of carrying out your suggestion at the present time. If these girls were sent to the institution you mention in Winnipeg it is doubtful if, when they reached the age of 16 or 18, they would be any better equipped to become reputable members of a community. It is unlikely that they could be placed in positions in Winnipeg and if they returned to the reserve at that age there would be no one to supervise them.

I feel that disciplinary measures should be taken at the Cross Lake School.

You might write to me again about these girls at the end of the current academic year.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. G.E. Trudeau, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Cross Lake, Man.
Sir,

In September last, Mr C. Roberts, Acting Indian Agent, brought to the attention of the Department, the matter of certain alleged Protestant children being admitted as pupils of The R.C. Residential School at Cross Lake, namely, the children of Albert Richard of Cross Lake Band, and I would refer you to Mr R.A. Hoey's letter No: 123-1-10 dated 26th September 1941, in reply. Mr Roberts also wrote to the Principal of the R.C. School at Cross Lake in the matter, and I enclose herewith for your information, a copy of Father Trudeau's reply.

Section 10, sub-section 2 of the Indian Act provides that "...no Protestant child shall be assigned to a Roman Catholic School,....and no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Protestant school,...", but the Act does not define just what shall determine the religion of the child.

From Father Trudeau's letter, it appears clear that he accepts the Baptismal Ceremony as being the determining factor, but from the final paragraph of Mr Hoey's letter, mentioned above, it would appear that the wishes of the father, (Protestant in the case of Albert Richard's children), should have some bearing on the matter.

I beg to mention now, an instance which came to my attention yesterday. John Paupanakis, No; 590 Norway House Band, was married about 1923. He is a Protestant, and his wife a Catholic. They were married by an Anglican Minister. Their eldest child, Frank, was brought up as a Protestant, and attended the Jack River Church of England Day School here until he passed Grade 8. Two other children were baptized by a Catholic Priest

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines & Resources
Ottawa, Ont:,

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6261, file 577-10, part 1)
and are at present pupils in the R.C. Residential School at Cross Lake. Yesterday John Paupanakis approached the Principal of the United Church Residential School here at Norway House, with a view of having another of his children, (also I understand, baptized by a Catholic Priest), admitted to this school after the coming summer holidays. What is to determine the proper school to which this child should be sent; the wish of the father, who is Protestant, or the fact that the child was baptized according to the Catholic faith?

There is quite a number of cases of this kind, which are causing considerable dissension, and I beg to request that a definite and unmistakable ruling be brought down, legal if possible, stating clearly what shall determine the religion of minor children; whether they shall be regarded as being of the same religion as their father, regardless of baptism, or otherwise. There may possibly be something in Civil Law which would settle the matter. If such a legal ruling can be made, I would recommend that Section 10, subsection 2 of the Indian Act be amended so as to include such ruling.

For your further information, and to show the extent to which this mixing up of children has occurred, I am attaching hereto a copy of a statement handed to me some months ago, by the Principal of The Norway House Residential School. I may say that I have checked this statement with Census records as secured last summer by Mr C. Roberts, as to the religion of the parents concerned, and with the quarterly returns of the two schools concerned, with respect to the children. I may also say that prior to the Census record taken last summer, there were no records on file showing the religion of the Indians. With regard to the third paragraph of the statement, I may say that the Census records taken last summer, show both Norman Yellowback and Edmund McKay as belonging to the United Church, though they may possible have become affiliated with the R.C. Church since that time.

Your obedient Servant

[Signature]

P.G. Lazenby
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs. (RC 10, Volume 6261, file 577-10, part 1)
St: Joseph's Indian Residential School  
Cross Lake, Man:  

1st October 1941.

Dear Sir,

I reply to yours of September the 8th received last week concerning the complaint received from the Chief and some of the Councillors of Cross Lake at Treaty Time, that some Protestant children had been admitted to the St Joseph's Indian Residential School, I do not see any ground for such a complaint as all the children that you mentioned in your letter have been baptized in the Roman Catholic religion on the request of their parents. When these children were baptized as Catholics their parents have promised that these children would be brought up in the Catholic religion, and this is the reason why they have been accepted in the school after they were Catholics.

All the children of Albert Richards and his wife are Roman Catholic so Albert is the only one of the family who is Protestant.

Tommy and Ada Eleonore Ross were baptized Catholic long ago on the request of their parents. In fact I have baptized Eleonore Ross myself about ten years ago.

Thomas Albert Ross is the only one who was accepted into the school before being baptized a Catholic, but as his mother wanted him to be a catholic he had to be taken into the school to be taught the religion before he could be baptized. Another reason for accepting him before being a catholic is that his mother could not take care of him and the child was destituted.

As a matter of fact we do not accept into the school Protestant children and we have refused this favour to many people of Cross Lake who had wished earnestly to have some of their children into our school.

Hoping that this is found satisfactory to, I remain,

Yours very truly,

Signed:- G.E.Trudeau O.M.I.  
Acting Principal

Mr C.Roberts,  
Acting Indian Agent,  
Norway House, Man.

Ottawa,
May 18, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th ultimo, with reference to certain children who are pupils of the Cross Lake Indian Residential School.

Our files have been reviewed and it is found that the application forms for all of the children mentioned in your letter were forwarded to your office and signed by you approving their admission to the Cross Lake School. In every case the information given on the application form indicated that the pupil was eligible for admission as a grant-earning pupil to the Cross Lake School. You signed each application and took no exception whatsoever to any statement made on the form. It was impossible for the Department to do other than approve the admission of these children in view of the fact that you, as Indian Agent, are presumed to be fully conversant with all the local conditions and naturally, when you approve the application form, the Department sees no reason why the child should not be admitted.

Unless you make full inquiries in each case when an application is handed to you for your approval, the condition to which you refer in your letter will continue.

Yours truly,

Mr. P.G. Lazenby,

Sir,

I beg to forward herewith an Application for the admission to the Cross Lake Roman Catholic Residential School, of Therese Mabel Ross, daughter of Lazarus Ross, No; 391 Cross Lake Band, signed by the father of the child.

On receipt of this application from Father Trudeau, the Principal of the Cross Lake School, I checked up the details as to band number, religion etc; with this office records, and found that the religion given was "United Church". I therefore wrote to the United Church Missionary at Cross Lake asking him to see the child's father and verify this. However, I have to-day seen Lazarus Ross, the child's father, and talked the matter over with him, and he gave me the following information;

Lazarus Ross and his wife are both members of the United Church. They have two children now in the United Church Residential School at Norway House. When the above mentioned daughter, Therese Mabel Ross was five years old, she was given to her grandfather to look after temporarily. The grandfather is a member of the Roman Catholic Church, and when the child Therese Mabel was seven years old, two years ago, he had her baptized by the Roman Catholic Missionary, without consulting her parents, although he had not adopted the child, and was in no way her legal guardian, and although the child had already been baptized as a baby into the Church and religion of the parents, by Rev: W.W.Shoup, who was at that time United Church Missionary at Cross Lake. Lazarus Ross stated that he would rather have his daughter Mabel Therese in the United Church School at Norway House where he already has two other children, than in the R.C.School at Cross Lake. When asked why, if this was the case, he had signed the application to have her admitted to the R.C.School at Cross Lake, he replied that his grandfather had already put the child in this school, and the Principal had asked him to sign the application, telling him that he would talk the matter over with the Indian Agent. However, since receiving the application, I have had no opportunity of talking this over with Father Trudeau.

In view of the foregoing, I should be glad to be advised if this child Therese Mabel Ross, is to be regarded as a Roman Catholic, and a proper candidate for the R.C.School at Cross Lake, or if she is still to be regarded as Protestant, as her father is, and be admitted to the United Church Residential School at Norway House as her father wishes. If the Department will make a definite ruling in the matter, kindly return the application, as I have not as yet signed it.

Your obedient Servant

P.G.Lazenby
Indian Agent.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.:

With further reference to Mr Philip Phelan's letter No; 123-1-10 of the 2nd December 1942, regarding the application for admission to the Cross Lake R.C. Indian Residential School of Therese Mabel Ross, daughter of Lazarus Ross of Cross Lake, and my reply thereto of December 11th, I beg to say that Mr H.Meadows, the United Church Missionary at Cross Lake, has advised me that according to the church records there, this girl, Mabel Therese Ross was baptized at the United Church in Cross Lake, on April 5th 1934 by Rev. S.D.Gaudin D.D. As stated in my letter to the Department of December 11th, I wrote to the Principal of the Cross Lake Residential School, asking to advise me how this child came to be a candidate for this school, as her parents and all the rest of the family were members of the United Church, and I quote the following from his letter in reply:

"When Therese Mabel Ross was about five years old, her father Lazarus Ross gave her to his father to stay with him. At the same time Lazarus told his father: I want this little girl to be a catholic and to pray like you. Not very long after Therese Mabel was baptized in the Catholic Religion by Rev. Father A.Chamberland on the 24th December 1939 and has been a catholic since that time. She then became eligible candidate for Catholic School as the law of the Department is 'No catholic child should be in a protestant school and vice versa.'

So last summer, Therese Mabel Ross being of school age I asked her father Lazarus Ross if he intended to put his daughter at the Cross Lake School? He answered me "I want to put her here but I don't know what to do now as I saw the Indian Agent about this not long ago and he told me that I could not put her in the Cross Lake School but at Norway House School". Then I told Lazarus Ross: may be the Agent does not know your daughter is catholic. Being a catholic she ought to be in a catholic school. If you want to put her in our school you can do it, so he did."

A proof that he wanted his daughter here is that he himself duly signed the application form for admission." Before leaving for the harvest Lazarus Ross told his wife to bring the little girl after the children holidays. The day the children came back to school Mrs Lazarus Ross brought her daughter here which is another proof that Lazarus Ross and his wife wanted their daughter to be in the Cross Lake school.

"I believe that these facts will show you how Therese Mabel Ross came to be a candidate of the Cross Lake

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6261, file 577-10, part 1)
school and that she was neither put here by her grandfather as you stated in your letter nor against the will of her parents who deliberately signed the Application form for Admission and brought her to the school."

From the last preceding paragraph, quoted from the Principal's letter, it might appear that I had stated in my letter to him that the girl had been placed in the school by her grandfather, and against the will of her parents, which would not be correct. What I did was to mention in my letter what Lazarus Ross, the girl's father had stated to me, and to make this particular matter clear I enclose herewith the duplicate copy of the letter I wrote to the Principal.

I beg to refer you to my letter of April 15th 1942, and the penultimate paragraph thereof particularly, in which I asked that if possible, the Department make some definite ruling in the matter of determining what shall be regarded as the religion of an Indian minor. My only concern in this matter of course, is to enable me to see that children of school age are sent to the proper school, and until such a ruling is made, these difficulties will undoubtedly continue.

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent

Dear Mr. Phelan:

A few days ago I received a letter from the Indian Agent at Norway House quoting the following from the Department's letter:

"From the information we have received we do not feel that William Halcrow is eligible for admission to the Cross Lake School, and you should so inform the Principal."

Then Mr. Lazenby adds:

"If this boy, William Halcrow, is now in the Cross Lake School, will you kindly see that he is returned to his home."

I am rather surprised to just hear that this boy, William Halcrow, was not eligible for the Cross Lake School as the application for admission had been sent with the September quarterly return. I also regret that the Department before pronouncing on the eligibility of this child did not ask me for the particulars, if he thought this boy could not be admitted to our school.

I am at a loss to send this boy home now as notified by Mr. Indian Agent Lazenby. The reason is that the father, Wilkie Halcrow, is working at the God's Lake Gold Mines and the mother is somewhere around Le Pas working too. The boy being homeless at present, the only solution I can see is to keep him in the School until I further hear from the Department.

I would like to know why this boy, William Halcrow, is not eligible for admission to the Cross Lake School as I don't see why he can't be. The boy was baptized Catholic on the 8th of March 1935 by Rev. Father H. Boissin and was never baptized Protestant that I know of. At the time that Wilkie Halcrow was married to Alphonseine Cook I consented to perform the ceremony only after the solemn promise had been
made by both parties that all the children born from their marriage, either boy or girl, should all be baptized and brought up in the Catholic faith. So the promise was made and witnessed as you can see by a copy of the Church Records sent herewith.

So last fall when William Sandy Halcrow was brought to the school by his mother, I never thought for a moment that this child could not be eligible for the school. The Application form could not be signed by the father as he was at God's Lake about 160 miles from here. I told the mother about it but she answered that her husband had told her to put the child in the school. Any way she was forced to do it as she was not receiving enough support from her husband and was almost starving here at Cross Lake with her son.

After Mrs. Halcrow had put her son into the School she wrote to her husband and told him. He answered her that he was glad that his boy was in the school here.

So considering these facts I am hoping that the Department will see that this William Halcrow is eligible for the school and will soon notified me that he is admitted to our School.

With kind personal regards, I remain,

Yours Sincerely,

G.E. Trudeau, O.M.I.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Mr Philip Phelan's letter No; 123-1-10 of the 17th instant, enclosing a copy of a letter written by Rev: Father Trudeau, Principal of The Cross Lake R.C.Residential School, regarding the Application for Admission to that school of William Halcrow, son of Wilkie Halcrow of Cross Lake Band.

I was not aware that this boy's mother had gone to The Pas. When I wrote the Department on October 12th last regarding the boy's application, I understood that she was at home on the Cross Lake Reserve.

I note from Father Trudeau's letter to the Department, that this boy was baptized into the Catholic faith, and that at the time of their marriage, the parents had apparently promised that any children born to them should be brought up in the Catholic faith. Then against that there is the father's written and signed declaration to the effect that he wishes the boy removed from the Cross Lake R.C.School, and placed in the U.C.School at Norway House.

The Application for Admission in this case has been signed by the mother, but not by the father. If the father refuses to sign the application, what is to be regarded as the determining factor in rendering a decision as to what school the boy should be sent? Is it to be the wishes of the father, or the fact that the boy was baptized into the Catholic faith? I have asked the Department on a previous occasion, for a definite ruling in this matter, but no such ruling has as yet been given so far as I know, and until

- such -

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6261, file 577-10, part 1)
such a ruling is handed down, these difficulties are bound to continue.

Section 10, sub-section (2) of the Indian Act provides that "...no Protestant child shall be assigned to a Roman Catholic School,...and no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Protestant school...", but the Act does not define what constitutes a "Protestant Child" or a "Roman Catholic Child".

My only reason for asking that some definite ruling be given as above, is that I may be able to see that children are placed promptly in the proper schools when they are of the proper age.

I have written to Wilkie Halcrow, the father of the boy in question, at God's Lake, and enclose herewith for your information, a copy of the letter I have written him. When I receive his reply, I will write further to you.

Dear Sir:

In a letter received two days ago from Mr. F.G. Lazenby, Indian Agent at Norway House, I am notified that the Department was not prepared to approve the Admission of Johnny Scatch, Illa Monias, and Frederick Ross to our School. The Agent quotes The Department's Letter No: 123-1-10 of the 1st of April 1943;-

"In view of the recent report of Dr. Corrigan regarding the health conditions at this school, The Department feels that it is inadvisable to admit any further children at the present time. Consequently we are not prepared to approve their admission."

I wish to point out to the Department that these children were not admitted into the school since the recent visit of Dr. Corrigan but have been in the school since the 1st of October 1942. The Applications for Admission of these children could not be sent before, as I had to wait for the coming of the doctor to fill in the physical examination. The doctor came in the beginning of September and his next visit was only in March. Six months without the visit of the doctor seems to be too long.

Since the visit of the doctor I have discharged two girls at the end of the March quarter. Then two boys and one girl have been sent to Norway House Hospital. Another girl who was sent to the hospital and was under doctor's examination for three weeks was sent back to her home by the doctor. I have also sent home two girls who had been sick for more than a month. In fact the doctor told me to send one home as he thought she had T.B.

So at present we have only 89 children in residence, counting Johnny Scatch, Illa Monias and Frederick Ross.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6261, file 577-10, part 1)
When I received the notification from the Agent I could not send these three children home as their parents had gone away for rat hunting and I had no means to send them.

So as these children were not admitted into the school since the recent report of doctor Corrigan, but have been in since the 1st of October, and owing to the fact that I shall not be in a position to send them home until the return of their parents, at the end of May, I am kindly asking the Department to approve of their admission. Our school is approved for 100 children and at present even counting these three children we have only 89 in residence. Dr. Corrigan thought that if we had so much sickness lately, it was because our school was too crowded. The only reason, I think is that there has been an epidemic of influenza on the reserve since the middle of January which reached its peak in March. Nearly all the Indians had it twice and so the children. There was no doctor and no nurse on the reserve to stop this epidemic and the nurse of the school had more than she could do here. Even if she had wanted to try to do it, she did not have the medicines to do it.

As I could not send these children home and as it is expensive to keep them without receiving the grant, I hope that the Department will be prepared to approve their admission now.

Yours very truly,

G.E. Trudeau, O.M.I.
Principal.

P.S. The health of the children seems to be fairly good now.

In my letter of April 1st, I stated that the Department was not prepared to admit Johnny Seatch, Illa Monias, and Frederick Ross to the Cross Lake Residential School. Under these circumstances it has been decided to approve their admission and you may so inform the Principal.

Philip Phelan,

I have your letter of the 7th instant, enclosing application for the admission of Lillian Bruce to the Cross Lake Indian Residential School. 11th December 1943.

Mr. P.G. Lazenby
Indian Agent.
Norway House, Man.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letters of October the 27th to Charlie Sinclair & Sandy Cook, I wish to let you know that these two men and all the members of their families are Catholics. These boys went astray and for a while joined the United Church but they soon found out their mistake and came back to the Catholic faith in which they had been brought up. Sandy Cook came back to his church three years ago and Charlie Sinclair one year and a half ago. I must point out also that Sandy Cook's wife and children were never members of the United Church but himself only.

Regardless of this fact I don't see why you could refuse to these men the privilege to choose for their children the school where they want to send them, and this without being obliged to give their reasons for doing so.

On the application forms signed by the parents and witnesses it is said clearly to which religion the children belong, and the forms which are sent with the quarterly returns for the admission of the new children during the quarter also mention the religious denomination of the parents. As these are official documents I don't see why you have to write for some more explanations unless you do not consider these official documents to be truthful.

As for Christina Sinclair I told Charlie that she was under age but he insisted on having her in the school as he was hard up this year and did not want her to be destitute at home. In fact Charlie is very poor this winter as he has killed only one fox which is far from being sufficient to provide for himself and family.

Yours very truly,

Signed:- G.E. Trudeau O.M.I.
Principal

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

Cross Lake, Man. 17th Feb. 1944.

Mr. P. G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent,
Norway House, Man.

Dear Mr. Lazenby:

Regarding the pupil 0175 Catherine Hastings as the Department did not want the children of God's Lake to come back to school this year and as I have heard that the Hastings family is infected with tuberculosis I have decided to discharge this girl. Unfortunately I have forgotten to put her on my list of the discharge of pupils for the December Quarterly Return. So I am forwarding you the two copies of the official discharge for her.

I did not want to leave the girl any longer on the Records as I could take some new girl in while this one was not in residence.

There is another girl who was shown on my June Quarterly and by mistake was omitted on my September and December Quarterly Return. She is #0194 A Margaret Cook. Will you please ask the Department to pay us for the two Quarters in which this girl was in Residence as we can not afford to loose this amount. This girl is in Residence and her Admission to the School has been approved by the Department.

So I am sending you a Quarterly Return Form on which I am putting her for the two quarters she was in residence and not shown by mistake on the original quarterly Returns. The amount for the two quarters will be $87.50.

As Margaret Cook Number has been given to Frances Apitagan #0194 I am giving to Margaret Cook #0194

Hoping you will be able to obtain the payment for these two quarters as it would be too expensive in a mistake, when we are so short of money.

Yours very sincerely,

G. E. Trudeau, O.M.I.

Norway House, Man:
17th August 1944.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

With reference to Mr Philip Phelan's letter No. 123-1-10 of July 3rd last, regarding Elsie, Margaret, and May D'Arcis, for whose admission to the Cross Lake R.C. Residential School the Department has received a request, I beg to say that the father of these children, Mr William D'Arcis, has given me the following information:

The ages of the children are as follows:

Elsie D'Arcis Age 11 Born 8th May 1933
Margaret D'Arcis " 7 Born 27th March 1937
May D'Arcis " 4 Born 24th Sept: 1939

The mother of these children was Eva Bee, who was No; 115 Gods Lake Band. The mother died in January 1940, and her band number was deleted from the annuity pay list for 1941. William D'Arcis, the father, took Eva Bee off the Gods Lake reserve and lived with her without being married to her, and the above children are all illegitimate. None of the children have ever been received into membership of the Gods Lake Band, and have never been paid treaty annuity, and of course, they have no band number.

The above three children have the same status now, as the two children of Harry D'Arcis had before they were admitted to treaty as per Departmental letter 62-123 dated 18th September 1939, and who were admitted to treaty as members of Gods Lake Band under No; 77, the band number of their mother and later transferred to their own band numbers, 174 and 175 at the 1941 treaty payment.

Should a vote of the Gods Lake Band be taken next treaty payment, in 1945, on the question of admitting the above three children to membership in the band under new band numbers? As stated above, the band number of their mother was deleted from the roll in 1941. When I receive the Department's reply, I will try to find William D'Arcis, the father of the children, who is at present on Lake Winnipeg, and have him sign applications for the admission of the children to Cross Lake School, though no band or band number could be stated on the applications at the present time.

F.G. Izzenby
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
August 31, 1944.

Mr. P.G. Lazenby, Indian Agent, Norway House, Man.

I have your letter of the 17th instant, with reference to Elsie, Margaret and May D'Arcis. I have brought to the attention of the Trusts Branch your inquiry regarding the taking of a vote to admit them as members of the God's Lake Band. You will be advised regarding this by the Trusts Branch at a later date.

In the meantime it has been pointed out to us that these children require institutional care and, provided they are physically fit, the Department approves their admission to the Cross Lake Residential School. It should be understood, however, that this is only a temporary arrangement and, in the event of it being decided later that they are not wards of this Department, payment of the grant will be discontinued. The usual application forms and certificates of health should be forwarded as soon as obtained.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I beg to forward herewith the applications for admission to the Cross Lake Residential School, (Jack River Branch) of the following children:

May D'Arcis
Margaret D'Arcis
Elsie D'Arcis

In connection with these applications, I beg to refer to Mr Philip Phelan's letter, File 123-1-10 of the 31st August 1944. It will be noted that I have not signed the recommendation for the admission to the school of Elsie D'Arcis, as, according to the statement of Dr Corrigan, this child has active tuberculosis. This child is in Norway House Hospital at the present time.

As advised in previous correspondence, none of the above named children have ever been paid as treaty Indians, nor regarded as belonging to any reserve. The parents were never married. The Mother was Eva Bell, No; 115 God's Lake Band, who died in January 1940, since which time her name has not appeared in the treaty pay list.

With reference to Mr Phelan's letter, I note that he states that the Trusts Branch were to advise me regarding the matter of taking a vote of the members of God's Lake Band to admit these children to treaty as members of that band, but to date no word has been received, although there may be a letter when our mail service is resumed.

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I beg to forward herewith another application for the admission to the Cross Lake Residential School, (Jack River, Norway House, Branch), of Elsie D'Arcis, who is not a treaty Indian.

In connection with this application, please refer to my letter of 15th December last, with which I forwarded applications for admission of this applicant's two sisters, May and Margaret, both these applications being recommended. The application for the admission of Elsie, however, though forwarded, was not signed by me, as the Doctor had stated that she had active tuberculosis. She was in hospital at that time. Dr Corrigan however now states that her condition has been arrested, and recommends that she be admitted to the school. This application is not signed by the father, as he died suddenly at God's Lake on December 6th last. The former application however was signed by the father.

These three children now have no parents, nor official guardians, and as they have all been in the Jack River School for over three years past, unofficially, I consider that they might now be admitted. The matter of their proposed admission into treaty is being dealt with in a separate letter.

P.G. Lazenby
Indian agent.

8th January 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept' of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I beg to refer to Mr Philip Phelan's letter, File 123-1-10 dated 31st August 1944, in which he advises that he has brought to the attention of the Trusts Branch the matter of the advisability of taking a vote of the Indians of God's Lake Band regarding the proposed admission to treaty as members of God's Lake Band, the three children of William D'Arcis, who are named Elsie, Margaret, and May respectively.

I have had no word from the Trusts Branch in connection with this matter as yet, and I have now to advise the Department that William D'Arcis, the father of these three children, died suddenly at God's Lake on December 6th last. They now have no parents or guardians, and this aspect of the matter should probably now be taken into consideration by the Trusts Branch.

If the Department approves of the taking of a vote to admit these three children as members of God's Lake Band, and the vote is favourable, should they be given a band number of their own, separate from any relatives that might still be living. The mother of these children, was a daughter of David Bee, No; 13 God's Lake Band. David himself died last January, but his wife is still living, though she is now about 85 years old.

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 16, 1945.

P. G. Lazenby, Esq., Indian Agent, Norway House, Manitoba.

I wish to refer to your letter of January 8th last, regarding the admission of Elsie, Margaret and Roy D'Arcis into the membership of the God's Lake Band.

Please forward a report giving all the particulars regarding these children, as it is our understanding that their mother lived for years as the common-law wife of William D'Arcis who was non-Indian.

It will not be necessary to have the Band vote on their admission, as the authority to admit to membership is vested in the Superintendent General, not in the Band. On receipt of your report their eligibility for membership will be considered and you will be advised as to the decision.

J. J. Allen,
Superintendent,
Reserves and Estates.

Dear Dr. Moore,

I have just returned from a trip to Cross Lake where I checked over the schools. I found one thing which I did not think was quite right, namely that Day School pupils were being taken in the Boarding School. I believe there were 22 Day School students over and above the 90 students already in attendance as boarders. On top of this two or three of the 22 are non-treaty children. I consider this school already overcrowded as I have pointed out to the Department before. I believe this is a highly undesirable situation to exist, and in view of the fact that there is now in operation at Cross Lake a Public School, I see no reason that non-treaty children should be allowed to attend the boarding school. The same condition exists at the Roman Catholic boarding school at Norway House.

I suppose I do not need to point out my opposition to this idea. But aside from the daily and constant exposure of a select group of children to the common acute infections they are exposed to such things as lice, scabies and impetigo with its resulting disadvantages. As a matter of fact this was how the matter was first drawn to my attention. I noticed that one of the Boarding School Students was lousy. Father Chamberland has told me it is a very bad arrangement to have day students and boarders mingling together, as it is so much harder to maintain discipline.

I talked this matter over carefully with Indian Agent Goodman and we both believe this was a bad time at which to make any sudden or drastic change. With the advent of the Family Allowance, all children are compelled to go to school where schools are available, and this has necessitated the crowding in to the Boarding
Boarding schools of day pupils. The fault is entirely our own as we have not sufficient day schools. For that reason I do not see why the Boarding Schools should be penalized in taking in these extra children. The Family Allowance Act states that children must attend schools only where schools are available and if the school is not available there is no reason that the allowance should not be paid. The Government cannot and will not deprive children of privileges because of its own neglect. In the case of the two non-treaty children at Gross Lake there is absolutely no reason why they should not be attending the Public School.

Could I have your instructions on this matter.

Yours very truly,

Cameron Corrigan, BSc, MD.
Ottawa, April 2, 1946.

Dear Father Trudeau:

We are in receipt of a letter from Dr. Corrigan, directing our attention to the fact that 22 Indian children are attending the classrooms at the Cross Lake Residential School as day students. Of this number, two or three are non-Treaty children.

Certainly, the non-treaty children should not be attending, and I doubt very much if it is advisable to have day students. There is always the danger of bringing contagious diseases into a residential school where the pupils are receiving special attention. I would appreciate hearing from you in the matter and I hope that you will be in a position to tell me that you have discontinued the day school pupils or that you will do so within the next month or so.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
